University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: In lystes thries and aye slayne his foo
This ilke worthy knyght . / had be also
Somtyme with the lord of Palatye
Ayen an othre hethen in Turkye
And eủeremore he had . / a souereyne prys
And though that he was worthy . / he was wys
Of his port . / as meke as is a maide
And nev̉er yit . / no velanye saide
In all his lyf . / onto nomaner wight
He was a verrey . / parfyght gentil knyght
For to y tellen you . / of his arraye
His hors were good . / but he was nat gaye
Of Fustian . / he wered . / Agepoıı̄un
All be smoterid . / with his haburgeoıı̄un
For he was late come . / from his viage
And went for to don . / his pilgrimage
With hym there was . / his sone a yong squyer
A louyer and a lusty bacheler
With lokkes crulle . / as they were leide on presse
Of . / xx . / yere of age . / he was I gesse
Of his stature . / he was of euyn lenght
And wonderlye . / delyuere . and gret of strenght
And he had be somtyme . / in chyuachy
In Flaundres . / in Artoys . / and in Picardye
And born hym wele . / as of so litle space
In hope to stonden . / in his ladys grace
Embroided was he . / as it were a mede
All full of fresshe floures . / white and rede
Synging he was . / / or floytyng alle the daye
He was as fressh . / as in the monethe of maye
Short was his gowne . / his sleuys long ⁊and wide . /
Wele coude he sitte on a . hors . / and faire ride
He coude wele songes make . / and wele endyte
Iuste and eke daunce and wele portray and write
So hote he loued . / that be nyghter tale
He slepith namore . / than dothe a Nityngale
Curteys he was . / lowlye and seruisable
And carf beforn his fadre at the table . /
A . / yoman had he . / and seruauntes nomo
Atte that tyme . / for him liste to ride so . /
And he was clad . / in Cote . / and hode of grene
A . / shef of Arwes . / bright and kene
Vndre his belt he bare full thriftelye
Wele coud he dresse . / his takill yomanlye
His arwes drowped not . / with federys lowe
And in his hande he bare a myghty bowe
A . / Nothed had he . / wᵗith a browne visage
Of woodcraft / . wele cowde he alle the vsage
Vpon his Arme . / he bar a gay. braser
And be his side . / a swerde and a bokeler
And on that othre side . / agay daggere . /
Harneysed wele . / as sharpe as poynt of spere
A Cristofere on his brest . / as siluer shene
And horne he bare . / the bawdryk was of grene
A Foster was he . / sothely as I gesse
There was also . / a Nonne . / a Prioresse
That of hir smyling . / was ful symple ⁊and coye
Here grettest oth . / was but be seynt Loye
And she was called . / madame . / Eglentyne
Ful wele she song . / the seruice diuine
Entuned in hir Nose . / full semely
And frenche she spak . / ful fayre and fetysly
After the scole at Stradford . / of the bowe
For frensh of Parys . / was to here vnknowe
At mete wele . I taught . / was she wᵗith alle
She lete no morsel from hir lippes falle
Ne wete hir fyngers /. in here sawce depe
Wele cowde she carye . / a morsel ⁊and wele kepe
That no drope . / ne fil nat on hir brest
In curtesye was set . / full mochel hir lest
Hir over lippe . / wiped she so clene
That in hir cuppe . / was there no ferthyng sene
Of . / Grece . / whan she had dronken hir draught
Ful semely aftir hir mete she raught
And sikerly she was of gret disport
And ful plesaunt . / and amiable of port
And peyned hir / to cownterfete chere
Of cowrte . / and to be estatlich of manere
And to be holden . / digne of reuerence
But for to speken . / of hir conscience
She was so charitable . / and so pitous
She wolde wepe . / yf she sawe a / Mows
Caught in a trappe . / ⁊and it were ded and bledde
Of smale houndes . had she that she fedde
With rosted flessh . / and milke or wastelbred
But sore wepte she . / yf oon of hem were ded
Or yf men smote it . / with a yerde smerte
And alle was conscience . / and tendir herte
Ful semelyche . / hir wympyll . / pynched was
Hir nose was streyght . / hir eyen as grey as glas
Hir mouthe ful smal . / and therto softe ⁊and rede
But sikirlye she had a . fayre forhede
It was almost . / a span brode I. trowe . /
For hardely she was vnder growe . /
Ful fetys was hir cloke . / as I was ware
Of smal corall . / abowte hir harme she bare
A peyre of bedys . / gawdeed all wᵗith grene
And theron heng . / a broche of golde full shene
On which ther was crowned wᵗith a . / crowned . / A . /
And after amor vincit omnia . /
Another Nonne . / with hir had she
That was hir Chapeleyn . / and prestis thre
A Monke there was . / a fayre man for the maistrye .
And owte ridere . / that loved wele venerye
A manly man . / to ben Abbot able
Full many a deynte hors . / had he in stable
And whan he rode . / men myght his bridel here
Gyngelyng . / in a whistelyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde . / as dothe the Chapelle belle
Ther as this lord was keper of the selle
The rule of seynt Maure . / and of seynt benet
By cause that it was olde . / ⁊and somdel streyte
This ilke monke . / lete olde thynges pace
And hilde after . / the newe worldis space
He yaf not of the text . / a pulled henne
That seithe that hunters . / ben not holy menne
Ne that a . monke . / whan he is recheles
Is likned to a . fisshe . / that is waterles
This is to saye . / a . monke wᵗith oute his cloister
But thilke text . / helde he not worth an oystre . /
And I. said his opinioıı̄un was good
What sholde he studye . / / and make hym silf wood
Vpon a booke . / in a . Cloyster alwey to pore
Or swynke wᵗith his hondes or laboure
As bit Austyn . / how shall the world be serued
Lat Austyn have his swynke . / to hym reserued
Therfor he was a . / pⁱricasoure a right
Grehoundes he had . / as swift as foule in flight
Of prikyng and huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust . / for no cost wold he spare
I. seye his sleuys . / purfiled at the honde
Wᵗith grys . and that the fynest of a londe
And for to festen his hoode vnder the chynne
He had of gold wrought . / a ful corious pynne
A love knotte . / in the gretter ende there was
His hede was ballid . / that shoon as any glas
And eke his face . / as it had be anoynt
A lord was he ful fatte . / and in good poynt
His eyen stepe /. and rollyng in his hede
That stemed . as a forneys of a lede
His bootes sowple . / his hors in gret astat
Nowe certanlye . / he was afaire prelat
He nas not pale as a . for pyned gost
A fat swan loved he best . of any rost
His Palfray was as brown as berie . /
A Frere ther was . / a wantoıı̄un ⁊and a mery
A . lymytoᵘur . / a . full solempne man
In alle the ordres fowre . / is non that can
So michil of daliaunce . / and faire langage
He had mad full many . / a mariage
Of yong women . / of his owne coste
Vnto his orded ordre . / he was a noble poste
Full wele beloued . / and familier was he
With Frankeleyns . / oủere all in his contre
And with worthy wommen . / of the town
For he had power of confessioıı̄un
And seide hym self . / more than a Curat /
For his ordre . / he was licenciat
Full swetlye . / herd he / confessioıı̄un
And plesaunt was . his absoluciou
He was an esye man . / to yeve penaunce
There as he wist . / to have a . good pitaunce
For vnto a pore ordre . / for to yeve
Is signe that a man is wele . I . shreve
For yf he yaf he durst make avaunt
He wist that a . man was repentaunt
For many a . man . / so hard is of his hert
He may not wepe . / all though he sore smerte
Therfor in stede of wepyng and praiers
Men mote yeve silủere . / vnto the pore Frerys . /
His typett was ay . / farsed full of knyfes
And pynnes . / for to yeve fayre wyfes .
And certanlye he had a mery note
Wele coude he singen . / and pleyn vn a . rote
Of ȝeddyng . / he bare wittirly the pris
His necke white was . / as the floure delice
Therto he was strong . / as a champioıı̄un
He knewe the taverns . / wele in euery town
And euerich hostiler . and tapster
Bet than a . lazer . / or a bexter
For vnto soche . / aworthy man as he
Accorded not . / as by his faculte
To have wᵗith soche lazeres .a . queyntaunce
It is not honest . / it may not avaunce
For to delen . with soche porayle
But alle with riche . / and sellers of vitayle
And ouer alle there . / as profyte shulde aryse
Curteyse he was . / and lowlye of seruyse
There was noman nowhere so vertuous
He was the beste . / begger in his hous
For though a . widewe . had not a shoo
So plesaunt was his Inprincipio . /
Yit wolde he have a ferthyng or he went
His purchase was wele better than his rent
And rage he couthe . / as it were a . whelpe
In love daies . / there cowde he moche helpe
For there he was not . / liche a . cloisterer
With a thred bare cope . / as a pore scoleer
But he was like /. a . mayster or a . pope
Of dowble worsted . / was his semy cope
That rong as a belle . / owte of the presse . /
Somwhat he lipsed . / for his wantounesse
To make his englissh . / swete vpon his tonge
And in his harpyng . / whan that he had songe
His eyen twynkeled . / in his hede a right
As don the sterrys . / in the frosty night
This worthy lymitoᵘur . was cleped hoberd
A marchaunt there was . / wᵗith a forked hede berde
In motle . and high on hors he sat
Vpon his hede . / a . Flaundres bever hat
His bootys clapsid . / faire and fetyslye
His reasoıı̄uns he spake full solemlye
Shewyng alweye . / the encres of his wynnyng
He wold the See . / were kept for any thyng
Bitwix Mydilbourgh . / and . orewelle
Wele cowde he in eschaunges shildes selle
This worthy man full wele his woordys be sette
There wist no wight that he was in dette
So estatlye was he of his goủernaunce
With his bargeyns . / and wᵗith his cheueshaunce
He forsothe a . worthy man . / was wᵗith all
But sothely to seyne . / I . not how men hym call /
A Clerke there was . / of Oxenford also
That on to Logyk . / had longe I. goo.
As lene was his hors . / as is a . rake
And he was right fat . / I . vndertake
But loked holugh . / and therto soberlye
Full thredbare . / was his overest Cowrtepye
For he had getyn . / hym no benefice
Ne was so wond wordly . / to have office
For hym was leuer . / have at his bedhed
Twenty bookes . / clad in white and red
Of Aristotle . / and of his philozophie
Than robes riche . / and Fedyl or sawtrye
But all by that . / he was A Philisofre
Yet had he ful litle golde. in cofre
But all that he myght . / of his frendis hente
On bookes . and on lernyng . he it spente
And besily can . for the sowles praye
Of hem that wherwhith . yaf hym to scoleye
Of stody toke he most cure ⁊and moste hede
Not awoord spake he more than was nede
And that was seid in forme and reuerence
And short and quyk . / and full of sentence
Sownyng in morall vertu . / was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne . / and gladly teche
A sergeaunt of the lawe . ware and wise
That often had be at Parvise
That was also full riche in excellence
Discrete he was . / and of gret reuerence
He semyd swich . / his wurdes weren so wise
Iustice he was . / full often in assise
By patent . / and be clene cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science . / and for his high renoıı̄un
Of fees and robes . / had he manye on
So gret a purchasoᵘur . / was nowhere non
All was Fee simple . / to hym in effect
His purchasyng . / might not be infecte
No where so besy .a . man . / as he there nas
And yit he semyd . / besyer than he was
In termes had he . / caas and domes alle
That fro the tyme . / of kyng william were falle
Therto he cowde endite . / and make a . thyng
There coude no wight . / pynche at his writyng
And every statute . / cowde he pleyn by rote
He rood but homly . / in a meede Coote
Gert with a . seynt of silke . / wᵗith barres smale
Of his arraye telle . / I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in his companye
White was his beerd . / as the daysie
Of his complexcioıı̄un . / he was sangweyn
Wele loved he by the morow . / a soppe in wyn
To leuen in delite . / was euer his wone
For he was . / Epymoners . / owne sone
That helde opynioıı̄un . / that pleyne delite
Was verrey . / felicite . / parfight
An howsholdere . / and that a . gret was he.
Seynt Iulyan . / was he in his contre
His bred his Ale . / was alweys after oon
A. better envyned man . / was neuer non
Wᵗithowte bake mete . / was nevir his hows
Of fissh of flessh . / and that so plentevous
It sw snewid in his howse . / of mete and drinke
Of alle deyntees . / that men cowde thynke
After the sondry seasons . / of the yere
So chaunged he his mete . / and his sopere
Ful many a fatt Pertrich . / had he in mewe
And many a Breme . / and many a luce . / in stewe
Woo. was his Cooke . / but his sawce were
Poynaunt and sharpe . / and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt . / in his laye halle laye
Stood redy coverd . / alle the long daye
At sessions there was he . / lord and sire
Ful ofte tyme he was knyght of the shyre
And Anelas . / and a gipser alle of silke
Heng at his girdill . / as white as morn mylke
A. shreve had he be . / and a . comptoure
Was nowhere soche . / a . worthy vauysoure
And Haburdassher . / and a . carpenter
A . webber . / a . dyer and a . tapster
And theye were clothed . / in on lyuere
Of a . solempne . / and a . gret fraternyte
Ful fressh and newe . / hir gere all piked was
Here knyfes were chaped . / all not wᵗith bras .
But alle wᵗith siluer . / wrough full clene ⁊and wele
Hir girdeles . / and hir powches euery dele
Well semed ech of hem . / a . faire burgeis
To sittyn . in a . yeldehalle . / on a . deys
Everich for the wisdom that he can
Was shapply . / for to be an Alderman
For catell had theye . / I . nowe and rent
And eke hir wifes . / wolde wele it assent
And elles certayne . / they were to blame
It is full fayre . / to be clepyd Madame . /
An goon to vigilies . / alle to fore
And have a . mantell . / riallich . I . bore
A . Cooke they had wᵗith them . / for the nones
To boyle the chekenes . / wᵗith the mary bones
And powder marchaunt . / / and tart ganyngale . /
Wele koude he knowe . / a . draught of London Ale . /
He cowde roste . / and sethe . / ⁊and boyle . / and frye . /
Make mortreux . / and wele bake a . pye
But gret harme was it . / as it thought me
That on his shene . / a . mormall had he
For blanke manger . / that made he wᵗith the beste
A . shipman was there wonnyng . / fer by weste
For ought I . wot . / he was of Dertmowthe . /
He rode vpon a . rownsy . / as he cowthe
In a . gowne faldyng . / to the knee
A . dagger hangyng . / by a . lace had hee
A . bowte his nekke . / vndir his arme a . downe
The hoot somere . / had made the hewe all browne
And certaynly he was a . verrey good felawe
Full many a . draught . / of wyne . / had he . I . drawe
Fro Burdeux ward . / whill the chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience . / tooke he no kepe . /
If that he faught . / and had the hier hande
Be water . he sent home . / to euery londe
But of his crafte . / to rekken wele his tithes
His stremys . / ⁊and his daungers hym besides
His herberwe . ⁊and his moone . / ⁊and his ledmannage
There was non soche . / frōm hulle . / to . Cartage
Hardy he was . / and wyse I vndirtake
Wᵗith many a . tempest . / had his berde be shake
He knewe alle the havenes . / as they were
From . Got . londe . to the Cape . of Defynystre
And euerye creyke . / in Brytayne ⁊and in spayne
His barge was I. clepyd . / the Magdeleyn
With vs ther was . / a . Doctor of Phisyk
And wympled wele . / and on hir his hed an hat
As brood as is a . bokeler . / or a . targe
A foote mantell . / abowte hir hepes large
And on hir feete . / a . peire of sporys sharpe
In felasship wele cowde she . lawgh ⁊and carpe
Of remedies of loves . / she knewe ꝑparchᵘunce
For she cowde of that art . / the colde daᵘunce
A. good man was there . / of religioıı̄un
And was a . pore Persoıı̄un of a . town
But riche he was . / of holy thought ⁊and wyrke
He was also . a . lerned man . / and a . clerke
That cristis gospel . / truly wolde preche
His parisshons . / devoutly wolde he teche
Benigne he was . / and wonder diligent
And in aduersite . / full pacient
And swich he was previd often sithes
Full lothe were he . to cursen for his tithes
But rather wold he yeve . / hym owte of dowte
Vnto his pore parisshons abowte
Of his offryng . / and of his substaunce
He coude in litle thyng . / have suffisaunce
Wyde was his parysshe . / ⁊and howsys fer a sondēr
But he ne laf not . / for reyne nor thunder
In siknesse nor in myschef to vesite
The ferrest in his parisshe most or lyte
Vpon his feet . / and in his hand a . staf
This noble ensample . / to his shepe he yaf
That furst he wraught . / ⁊and afterward he taught
Oute of the gospel . / he tho wurdes caught
And this figure he added . eke therto
That yf gold ruste . / what shall yren do .
For yf a . preste be fowle . / on whom we truste
No wondre is . / a lewde man to ruste
¶ And shame it is . / yf a . preste take kepe
A . sheten . shepperd . / and a . clene shepe
Wele ought a . preste . / ensample for to yeve
By his clennesse . / how that his shepe shold leve
He set nought . / his benefyce to here
And lete his shepe . accombred in myre
And ran to London . to seint powles
To seke hym a . Chauntery for sowles
Or wᵗith a . bretherhede . / to be wᵗith holde
But dwelle at hom . / and kepe wele his folde
So that the wolf . / ne made it not myscarye
He was a . shepperd . / and nat a . mercenarye
And thouh he were holy . / and vertuous
He was nat to sinfull men dispitous
Ne of his speche . / daungerous and digne
But in his techyng . / discrete and benigne
To drawen folke to heven . / by fairenesse
By good ensample . / this was his besynesse
But it were any persoıı̄un obstinat
What so he were . / of lowe or hih estat
Hym wolde he snybbe . / sharpely for the nones
A. bettir preste . / I trowe . nowhere is non is .
He wayted after no pompe . and reuerence
Ne made hym . a spiced . conscience .
But cristꝭes lore . / and his apostles twelue
He taught . / but furst he folowid it . hym selue
With hym there was . / a . plowmān . þᵗat was his brothre
That he had lad . of donge . / ful many a . fother
And . a . trewe swynker ; / and a . good was he .
Leuyng in pes . / and parfight charite
God loued he beste . / with alle his herte
At alle tymes . / though he gamed or smerte
And than his neyboᵘur . / right as hym self
He wolde thressh . / and therto dike and delf
For cristes sake . for every pore wight
With owte hire . / yf it lay in his myght
His tithes paid he full faire and wele
Bothe of his propre swynke and his catel
In a . tabbard he rode vpon a . mere
There was also . a . reve . and a . meller
A . sompnor . / and a . pardoner also
A. manciple and my self . / there were no mo
The millere was a . stowte carle for the nones
Full bigge he was . / of braun and eke of bones
That proued wele . / for oueral there he cam
At wrasteling he wold . / have aweye the ram
He was short shuldred a thikke knarre
There was no dore . that he ne wolde heve of harre
Or breke it at a . rennyng wᵗith his hede
His berd as any snowe sowe . / or fox was red
And therto brode . / as though it were a . spade
Vpon his hede . / and nose coppid he hadde
A . wert theron stood a . tuft of heris
Rede as the bristelis . / of sowes erys
His nosethyrles blak were and wide
A . swerd and a . bokeler . / bare he be his side
His mouthe as gret was . / as a . gret furneys
He was a . iangeler . / and a goliardeys .
And that was most of synne . / and harlotryes
Wele cowde he stele corn . / and tolle thries
And yit he had a . thombe of golde parde
A . white coote . and a . blewe hood werid he
A . bagge pipe wele cowde he blowe and sowne
And therwᵗithalle . / he brought vs owte of towne
A . gentill manciple . / was there of a . temple
Of which alle catowrs . / might take example
For to ben wise . / in beying of vitaile
For whedir he paied . / or tooke be tayle
Algate he wayted soo . / in his achate
That he was aye beforn and good estat
Nowe is not of god . / awele faire grace
That soche a . lewde mānnys witt . / shal pace
The wisdom of an heepe . of lernid menne
Of maistries had he . / moo than thries ten
That were of lawe . / expert and curious
Of whiche there were a . doseyne in that hous
Worthy to ben stiwardes . / of rent and londe
Of any lord that is in englonde .
To make hym lyve . / by his propir good
In honoure detles . / but yf he were wood
Or lyve as scarslye . / as hym list desire
And able for to helpen . / all a . shire
In any caas . / that myght falle or happe
And yit this manciple . / sette ther alder cappe
The Reve was a . sclendre . / colerik man
His berd was shave . / as nygh as euer he can
His heer was by his eres . / full rounde I . shorn
His toppe was dokked . / like a . preste beforn
Full long were his leggis . / and ful lene
I . like a . staf . there was no calf I . seene
Wele cowde he kepe a . Garner or a . Bynne
Wele he cowde kepe . a . garner . or a . bynne
There was non Auditoᵘur cowde on hym wynne
Wele wiste he . / be the drowte and be rayne
The yelding of his seed . / and of his grayne
Hys lordshippe . / his nete . his deyrie
His swyne . his hors . / his store and his pultrye
Was holly in this Reves . / gouernyng
And by his couenaunt . / yaf the rekenyng
Syn that his lord . was . twenty yere of age
There cowde noman . / bryng hym in arrerage
There nas bailyf nor herde . / nor othre hyne
That he ne knewe . / his sleight ⁊and his covyne
They were a . dred . / of hym as of the dethe
His wonnyng was ful fayre vpon an heth
With greene trees shadewid was his place
He cowde better than his lord . purchase
Full riche he was . a . stored pryuely
His lorde he cowde wele pleasen subtily
To yeve and leve hym . / on his owne good
And have a . thanke . / and yit a . coote . and a . hood
In youthe he had lerned . / a . good myster
He was a . wele good wright . / a . Carpentere
This Reve sat vpon . a . wele good stoot
That was . a . pomely . gray . / that hight scoot
A . long surcote of pers vpon he hade
And be his side . / he bare a rusty blade
Of Northfolke was this . Reve which I telle
Be side a . town . / men clepe it Baldeswelle
Tukkid he was as is a . Fryere abowte
And ever he rode . / the hynderest of the rowte
A . sompnoᵘur was there in that place . /
That had a . firy . / Cherubynnes face
For sawsfleme . he was . / wᵗith eyen narwe
As hoot he was . / and leccherous as a . sparwe
Wᵗith scallid browes . / blak and piled berd
Of his visage . / children weren aferd
Ther nas no quycke siluer . litarge . nor brimston
Boras . Orsure . ne oyle . of tartre non
Ne oynement . / that wolde clense and bite
That hym might helpe . / of his whelkys white
Nor on the knobbes . / sittyng on his chekes
Wele loued he garlyk . / onyoıı̄uns . and lekes
And for to drynk strong wyne . / red as blood
Than . wold he speke . and crye . as he were wood
And whan that he wele dronken had the wyne
Than wold he speke no worde but latyne
A . fewe termes had he . ij . or iij .
That he had lerned . / owte of somme decre
No wonder is he herd it alle the daye
And eke ye knowen it wele . / how that a . Iaye
Can clepe watte . / as wele as can the pope
But whoso cowde . / in othre thing hym grope
Than had he spent . / alle his philosophie
Ay . / questio quid iuris wolde he crye .
He was a . gentill harlot . and a . kynde
A . better felawe . / shold men not fynde
He wold suffre for a . quart of wyne
A . good felawe . / to have his concubyne
A twelmonthe . and excuse hym at the full
Full pⁱriuylich eke a . fynche cowde he pull
And he fonde . owhere . a . good felawe
He wolde techen hym . / to have non awe .
In soche a . caas of the Archedekenes curs
But yf mannys sowle were in his purs
For in purs . / he shold punysshed be .
Purs is the Archedekenes helle . / seide he
But wele I wote . / he leid right in dede
Of cursyng ought eche gylty man him drede
For curs wille sle . / right as assoilyng saveth
And also ware hym of a . significauit
In dawnger had he . / at his owne gise
The yong cherles . / of the Diocise
And knewe hir counseill . / ⁊and what was alle hir nede rede
A. garlond had he / sett vpon his hede
As gret as it were . / for an Ale stake
A. bokeler had he hym made of a . cake
With hym there rode . / a . gentil pardoner
Of rouncyvale . / his freend . / and his comper
That streight was come . / from the cowrt of rome
Ful lowde he song / come hider love to me
This sompnoᵘur bare to hym a stif burdoıı̄un
Was nevyr trompe . / of half so gret a . soun
This pardoner had heere . / as yelwe as wax
But smothe it heng . / as dothe a . strike of flax
By ounces henge his lockys . / that he had
And therwith . he his shuldres on sprad
But thynne it laye . be culpoıı̄uns . on and on
But hood for iolite . werid he non
For it was trussed vp . / in his walet
Hym thought he rode . / alle of the newe get
Discheuele saf his cappe . he rood alle bare
Swich glaryng eyen . / had he as an hare
A . vernicle had he sewid vpon his cappe
His walet beforn hym . / in his lappe
Bred . full of pardoıı̄un . / come from rome all hoote
A . voys he had . / as smal as a goet
No berd ne had he ne nevyr shuld have
As smothe it was . / as it were late shave
I trowe he were a . gildyng . / or a . mare
But of his crafte . / from barwik on to ware
Ne . Was there soche anothir pardonere
For in his male . / he had a . pelowbere
Which that he seide . was oure lady veill
He seid he had . / a . gobbet of the seill
That seint Petir had . / whan that he went
Vpon the see . / tille ihıı̄un . criste hym sent
He had a . cros of latoıı̄un ful of stones
And in a . glas he had pigges bones
But wᵗith theise relikes . / whan that he fonde
A. pore persoıı̄un . / dwellyng vpon londe
Vpon a . daye he gat hym more mony
Than the persoıı̄un gat . / in monthes twey
And thus he feyned . / flateryng ⁊and iapes
He made the persoıı̄un . / and the peple his apes
But truly to tellen . / at the laste
He was in chirche . / a . noble ecclīesiaste
Wele cowde he reden a . lessoıı̄un or a . story
But alderbest . / he song an offertory
For wele he wiste . / whan þᵗat song was songe
He muste preche . / and wele file his tonge
To wynne siluer / as he wele coude
Therfor he song . / so merily and loude
Nowe have I tolle you sothely in a . clause
Why that assembled was . this company
The astat the arraye . / the nombre ⁊and eke the cause
In southwerke at this gentil hostelery
That hight the tabbard . / fast by the belle
But nowe is tyme to you . for to telle
Howe that we beren vs . / that ilke night
Whan we were in that hostelery a . light
And after wille I tellen . / of oure viage
And alle the remenᵃnt of oure pilgrimage
But furst I pray you . / of youre curtesy
That ye ne recte it . not my vilony
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To tellen you here wordes and here chere
Ne though I speke . / hir wordys propirly
For this ye knowen . / as wele as I
Who shall tellen a tale . / after a . man
He mote reherse . as nyh as euer he can
Everich a . word of it be in his charge
All speke he nevir so rudely and large
Or elles he mote tellen . / his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thynges . / or fynde wordes newe
He may not spare . / all though he were his brothir
He mote also wele seye oo . word as an othir
Criste spake hym self . / ful brood in holy writt
And wele ye wote no velany is it
Eke plato / seithe . / whoso can hym rede
The wordes mot be . cosyne to the dede
Also I pray you . / foryeve it me
Though I have not set . / all folke in here degre
Here in this tale as they shold stonde
My witt is short . / ye may wele vndirstonde
Gret chere made oure . Oste . vs euerichon
And to sopere / sette he vs a non
And servid vs wᵗith vitayles / at the beste
Strong was the wyne / and wele drynke vs liste
A semely man oure . oste . was wᵗith all
For to ben a . Marchall in any lordes hall
A . large man he was . with eyen stepe
A . fayrer burgeys is . non in chepe
Bolde of his speche . / and wyse and wele I taught
And of manhode . / hym lackid right nought
Eke therto he was a . mery man
And after soper . / pleien he began
And spake of myrthe . / among othre thynges
Whan that we had made oure rekeninges
And seid thus . / nowe lordinges trulye
Ye be to me . / welcome . / right hertilye
For be my trouthe . / yf I shold not lye
I seye not this yere . / so merye a . companye
At onys in this herberwe . / as is nowe
Fayne I wolde do you myrthe . / and I wist howe
And of a . myrthe I am right nowe be thought
To don you ese . / and it shall coste nought
Ye gon to Cawnterburye . / god you spede
The blisfull martir . / quyte you your mede
And wele I wote . / as ye gon be the weie
Ye shapen you to talen and to pleie
For truly comfort . / and myrthe is non
To riden by the weie . / dombe . as a . ston
And therfor will I make you disport
As I said erst . / and do you som comfort
And yf you liketh . / alle by on assent
For to stonden . / at my Iugement
And for to warken as I shall you seye
To morowe whan we ridyn be the weye
Nowe be my faders sowle . / that is ded .
But if ye be mery . I wille yeve you my hede
Hold vp youre hondes . / wᵗithowte more speche
Oure cownseill was nat longe for to seche
Vs thought it was not worth to make it wis
And graunted hym . / withowte more avis
And bad hym seye . / his verdiȝt as hym liste
Lordinges qd he . nowe herkenyth for the beste
But take it not . I pray you in disdeyne
This is the poynt . / to speke short and pleyne
That eche of you . / to short wᵗith youre weye .
In this viage shall telle tales tweye .
To Cawnterbury . ward . I mene it soo .
And homwardes . / he shall telle othir too
Of aventures that have whilom falle
And which of you berith hym best of alle
That is to seyne . / that tellith in thys caas
Tales of best sentence . / and most solas
Shall have a . sopere . / at oure alder coste
Here in this place . / sittyng by this poste
Whan that we comyn ageyn from Cawnterburye
And for to make you the more merye
I wille my self . / goodly with you ride
Right at myn owne cost . / and be youre gyde
And whoso will my Iugement wᵗith seye .
Shall paye all that . we spende be the weie
And yf ye vouchesaf . / that it be soo
Telle me a . non wᵗithowte wurdes moo .
And I will erly . / shape me therfor
This thing was graunted . / and oure othes swore
With full glad hert . / and praiden hym also .
That he wold vouchesaf . / for to do soo .
And that he wold . be youre gouernour
And of oure tales . Iuge and reportour
And sett a . soper . / at a . certayne pris
And we welne ruled be at his devis
In hih and lowe . / and thus by on assent
We ben accorded . / to the Iugement
And thervpon the wyne was fet anon
We dronke and to reste went echon
Withoute any lenger tarying
At morowe whan . / the day gan to spring
Vp roos oure oost . and was oure alder cok
And gaderid vs to gidre in a . flok
And forthe we riden . / a . litte more than a . pas
Vnto the wateryng . / of seint Thomas .
And there oure oost . / gan his hors areste
And seid lordynges . / herkeneth yf ye lyste
Ye wot youre forwarde . / and I it you recorde
Yf evynsong . / and morowsong accorde
Lat se nowe . / who shall telle the first tale
As ever mote I drynke or ale wyne or Ale
Who so be rebelle . / to my Iugement
Shall paye for all that . / be the weye is spent
Nowe drawith Cutt . / or we forther twynne
He whiche that hathe the shortest shalbe gynne
Sir knight qd he . / my mayster and my lorde
Nowe drawᵗith Cutt . / for that is myn accorde .
Cometh nere qd he . / my lady prioresse
And ye sir clerke . / lat be youre shamfastnesse
Ne studieth not . / lay hond to . every man
Anon to drawe every wight began
And shortlye . / to tellen as it was
Were it be aventure . / soort . or caas
The sothe is this . / the cutt . fel vnto the knight
Of which full blythe and glad was euery wight
And tellen he moste his tale as it was resoıı̄un
By forward . / and by composicioıı̄un .
As ye han herd . what nedyth wordes moo .
And whan this goodman . / sawe that it was soo .
And that wise was . / and obedient
To kepe his forward . / be his free assent
And seid sithen I shall be gynne the game
Welcome be the cutt . a . goddes name
Nowe late vs ride . / and herkenyth what I seye
And wᵗith that worde . / we redyn forthe oure weye
And began . with a . mery chere
His tale anon and saide as ye maye here . /

It is a synne / and gret folye
To appaire any man / or hym diffame
And eke to bryng wifes / in soche fame /
Thou maist I nowe / of othre thyngꝭes sayne .
This droken miller. spake full sone ageyne .
And seide leue brothir Osewolde /. Prolog of the Meller .
Who hath no wyf / is noo kokholde
But I seye not that þᵘ art oon
There ben full good wifes many oon
Why art þᵘ angry wᵗith my tale nowe
I have a wif parde / as wele as thowe
Yitt nolde I not / for the oxen in my plouȝ
Take vpon me / more than I nowe
As demen on my self / that I were oon
I wilbe leve / that I am noon .
And husbond / shold not be inquisitif
Of goddes pⁱriuytes / ne of his wif
So he may fynde / goddes foison there
Of the remenᵃnt / nedeth nought to enquere
What shold I more seyne / but this Millere
He noldes his woordꝭes / for noman forbere
But tolde his cherles tale / in his manere
Me a thinketh / that I shall reherse hem here
And therfor euery gentill wight I praye
Demeth not for goddes love / that I saye
Of euil entent / but for I mote reherse
Here tales alle / be they better or werse
Or ellis falsen som of my matere
And therfor whoso list it not heere
Turne ouer the /leef and cheche chese anothir tale
For ye shall fynde I nowe . bothe gret 7 smale
Of storiall thyng / that touchyth gentilnesse
And eke moralite / and holinesse
Blameth not me / yf that ye chesen a mys
The myller is a Cherle ye knowe wele this
So was the Reve eek / and othir moo
And harlottry they tolden bothe two

fw.hi: tHe Mellers tale of the Reve.

div.l: Auyseth you wele / and put me owte of blame
And eke men shalle not . make ernest of game
Here endith the Prolog of the Meller
And here begynneth the Mellers tale of the Reve
WHilom there was dwelling at Oxenford .
A riche gnof that gestis held to bord
And of his crafte / he was a Carpenter
With hym there was dwellyng . a pore scoler
Had lerned art but alle his fantasye
Was torned for to lerne Astrologie
And coude a certain . of conclusions
To demen by interrogacions
If that men axed hym . what shalbe sawe in certayn oures .
Whan men shulde have drought or elles shoures
Or if men axed hym . whatt shal be falle
Of euery thyng . I may not rekne alle
This clerke was clepid / hinde Nicholas .
Of deme love he cowde and solas .
And therto he was slye / and full pryue
And like a maide . meke for to see .
A chamber had he in that ostelrie .
Allone wᵗithoute company
Full fetysly dight . wᵗith herbes soote
And he hym self as swete /. as is the roote
Of lycorice . or of any settewale
His Almagist . and bookes gret ⁊and smale
His Astirlabre /. longyng for his arte .
His Augrym stones / layne faire a parte .
On shelues cowched /. at his beddys hede .
His presse I couered . wᵗith a faldyng rede .
And all abowte above . there lay a gay sawtrye
On which he made /. a night melodie
So swetlye /. that alle the chambre ronge He tale of
And Angelus ad virginem . he songe .
And after that /. he songe the kynges note .
Full often tyme I blessed . was his mery throte
And thus the swete clerke . the tyme spente .
After his Freendys fynding /. and his rente
This Carpenter . had wedded . a newe wyf
Which that he lovyd / more than his lyf
Of xviij yere / she was of age .
Ialouse he was . and helde hir narwe in cage .
For she was wilde and yong / and he was olde
And demed hym . ben liche a cokewolde
He knewe not Caton . for his witte was rude
That bad men . wedde hir similitude
Menne shold wedde /. after hir estat
For youthe and yeld /. is often at debat
But sithen he was fallen in the snare
He must endure as othir folkes care
Faire was this yong wyf ; and there wᵗith all
As any wesille . hir body gentill and small
A ceynt she werid /. barrid all of sik
A barme clothe as whight as morne milke
Vpon hir lendes . full of many . a gore
White was hir smok . and broudellid all be fore
And eke behynde ; on hir coler abowte
Of coleblak silke ; wᵗithynne . and eke wᵗithoute
The tapes of hir white volipere .
Were of the same sute ; of hir colere
Hir filet brood of silke ; and sett wᵗith eiȝe
And sikyrly she had a licorous eye .
Full small . I pulled ; were hir browes twoo .
And tho were bente ; as blak as any sloo .
She was full more blisfull for to see /the Meller.
Than is the newe ; pereionett tree
And softer than the wolle is of a wethir
And be hir girdill . heng a purs of ledyr
Tassid wᵗith silke ; and perlid wᵗith latoıı̄un
In alle this world ; to seken vp and down
There is noman ; so . wise that cowde thenche
So . gaye a popelot ; or soche awenche
Full brighter was the shining . of hir hewe
Than in the toure ; the noble I forged newe
But of hir song / it was so loude and yerne
As any swalwe chitering on a berne
Therto she cowde skippe ; and make a game
As any kyde or calf ; folwyng his dame
Hir mouthe was swete ; as braket or þᵉ methe
Or horde of Apples ; laid in heye or hethe
Wynsyng she was ; as a Ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpright as a bolt
A broche she bare ; on hir love coler
As brood as is the boos . of a bokeler
Hir shoes were laced / on hir legges hie
She was a prymeroll ; a pigges nye
For any lord ; to liggen in his bedde
Or yit for any good yoman to wedde
Nowe sir and efte sir ; sobe fell the caas .
That on a daye this hende Nicholaas
Fille wᵗith this yong wyf ; to rage ⁊and to pleye
Whil that hir husbond . was at Osenaye .
As clerkes ben . ful subtill and full queynte
And priuely he caught hir ; be the queynte
And seid I wis ; but I may have my wille
For derne of the ; lemman I spille
And held hir harde ; by the haunche bones /.
And seid lemman love me wele at ones he Reues tal
Or I wille dien : als so god Me save
And she sprong as a colte ; dothe in the trave .
And with hir heed ; she wried fast aweye
She seide ; I wille not kisse the be my feye
Why labbe qd iche lat be Nicholas
Or /. I wille crye out harrow and allas
Do wey youre hondes ; for youre curtesye .
This Nicholas ; gan mercy for to crye .
And spake so faire ; and proferd hym so faste
That she hir love ; graunted hym at the laste
And swore hir othe ; be seynt Thomas of kent
That she wolde ben ; at his cōmmaundement
Whan that she may ; hir leiser wele aspie
Myn husbond is ; full of Ialousye .
That I but wayte wele ; and be priue
I woot right wele I am but dede qd she .
Ye mote ben full derne ; as in this caas .
Nay therof care ye not ; qd Nicholas
A clerke had litherly be sett his while
But yf he coude ; a Carpenter begyle
And thus they accorded ; and I sworn .
To waite a tyme ; as I have tolde you beforne
Whan . Nicholas had this euery dele .
And thakked hir ; abowte the lendes wele .
He kyssethe hir swete ; and takyth hir sawtrye
And pleieth faste ; and makith melodye
Than fille it thus ; that to the parissh chirche
Cristes owne werkes ; for to werche
This good wyf . went on an halydaye .
Hir forehede shoone ; as bright as any daye
So was it wasshe ; when she lete hir werke /
Nowe was there ; of that chirche a parysshe clerke tolde by the Meller.
The which was I cleped Absoloıı̄un .
Crull was his here ; and as the golde it shooıı̄un
And strowted as a fanne ; large ⁊and brood .
Full streight and even laye ; his ioly shood .
His rood was red ; his eyen . as grey as glas goos .
With powles windowes ; corven in his shoos
In hoses reed ; he went fetislye
I clad he was ; full small and propirlye
Alle in a kyrtill ; of light waget
Full faire and thikke ; be the poyntes sett
And thervpon ; he had agay surplice
As white as is the blosme ; on the rys
A mery child . he was so god me save .
Wele couthe he lete blood ; clippe and shave
And make a Charter of lond ; or aquetaunce
In twenty mane ; cowde he trippe or daunce
After the scole . of Oxenford thoo
And wᵗith his legges ; casten too . and froo
And pleyn songes ; on a smal Rubible
Therto he song somtyme a lowde quenyble
And as wele cowde he pleyen ; on a Giterne
In alle the town . nas brewhous ne Taverne
That he ne visited ; wᵗith his solas
There any Gaylard ; tapster was .
But sothe to seyne ; he was somdel squaymous .
Of fartyng ; and of speche daungerous
This Absolon ; thus ioly was and gaye
Goth wᵗith a Senser ; on the halydaye
Sensyng . the wifes ; of the parissh faste /
And many a louely look vn hem he caste He mellers tale.
And namlye vpon the Carpenters wyfe
To loke on hir hym thought a mery lyfe
She was so propyr . and swete . and licorous
I dare wele sayne ; yf she had be a mous
And he a catte he wolde hir hente anoon
This parissh clerke ; this iolye Absolon
Hath in his herte ; hath suche a love longyng
That of no wyf ; toke he noon ; offryng
For curtesye he seid ; he wold noon
The mone whan it was night full bright shoon
And Absolon his giterne ; hath I take
For ꝑparamours he thought for to wake
And forthe he gothe ; ioly and Amerous
Tille he come vnto the carpenteris hows .
A litill after cokkes had I crowe
And dressid vp by a shoppe windowe
That was vpoıı̄un ; the carpenters wall
He singeth in his vois gentill ⁊and small
Nowe dere lady ; yf thy will be
I pray you that ye wille rewe on me
Full wele accordaunt to his giteryng geternyng
This carpenter awook and herd hym syng
And spake vnto his wif and seid anoıı̄un
What Alison /; herist þᵘ not Absolon
That chaunteth thus ; vnder oure boures wall
And she answered therwith all
Yis god wot Iohn I here hym euery dell
This passeth forthe ; what will bet than well
From day to daye ; this Ioly Absolon
So woweth hir that hym is woo begon .
He waketh alle the night ; and alle the daye
He kembed his lokkes brode ⁊and made hym gay
So woweth he hir ; be menes and brokage
And swore he wolde ; been hir owne page .
He singeth brokkyng ; as dothe a nitingale
He sent hir pyment ; methe and spiced Ale .
And wafres pipyng hoot owte of the glede .
And for she was ; a towne he proferid mede .
For som folke wilbe wonne for richesse
And som for strokes ; and som for gentilnesse .
Somtyme to shewe lightnesse ; and maystrye .
He pleieth heroudes ; vpon a scaffold hie
But what availeth hym ; as in this caas .
She loueth so this hende Nicholas
That Absolon ; may blowe the bukkes horne
He ne hathe for his laboure ; but a scorne
And thus she maketh ; Absolon. hir Ape
And alle his ernest ; turneth to Aiape
For sothe is this prouerbs no lye
Men seyn right thus ; alwey they neighe flye
Maketh the fer leef ; to be lothe
And though that Absolon ; be wood or wrothe .
By cause that he was ferre ; from hir sight
This nigh Nicholas ; stood in his light
Now bere the wele ; hende Nicholas
For Absolon may weyle ; and sing allas
And so be felle it / on a Satirdaye
This Carpenter ; was goon to Osenay
And hende Nicholas ; and Alisoıı̄un
Accorded be ; to his conclusioıı̄un
That Nicholas shall shapen hem awile
This sely Ialouse husbonde ; to be gile
And yf so be the game went a right
She sholde slepen ; in his harme all night .
For this was his desire ; and hir alsoo . /
And right a noon ; wᵗithoute wordes moo .
But dothe full softe ; vnto his chambre carye
This Nicholas ; wolde no lenger tarye
Bothe mete ; and drink ; for a day or tweye
And to hir husbond bad hir for to seye
If that he asked ; after Nicholas
She shulde seye she nist where he was
Of alle that daye ; she saugh hym wᵗith eye
She trowed he was ; in A maladie
For no crye hir mayde ; coude hym calle
He nolde answere for nothyng that might falle
This passeth forthe ; all thilke satirdaye
That Nicholas stille in his chambre laye
And ete and slepe ; and dede what hym liste
Tille sondaye ; that the sonne gothe to reste
This selye Carpenter ; hath gret merveyle
Of Nicholas ; or what thyng might hym availe ayle
And seid I am a drad ; be seynt Thomas .
It stondith not a right with Nicholas
God shelde that he dyed sodenlye
This worlde is nowe full tikel sekirlye
I saugh a cors to daye borne to chirche
That on mondaye last ; I saugh hym werche
Goo vp qd he ; vnto his knave anoıı̄un
Clepe at his dore ; or knokke wᵗith a stou
Loke how it is ; and telle me boldlye
This knave ; gothe hym vp full sturdelye
And at the chambre dore ; whill that he stood /knokked
He cried and knokked as that he were wood
What howe what do ye maister Nicholay
How may ye slepen alle the longe day
But alle for nought ; he had herd not on woord
And hole he had full lowe vpon a boord
There as the catt was wont in to crepe
And at that hole ; he lokid in full depe
And at the laste ; he had of hym a sight
This Nicholas sat ever ; gapyng vpright
As he had ketid on the newe moone
And downe he gothe ; and tolde his maist̉er soone
In what array ; he saugh this ilke man
This Carpenter to blessen hym he began
And seide helpe vs seint Frideswide .
A man wot litle ; what shall hym be tide
This man is falle ; with his Astronomye .
In som . woodnesse ; or in som agonye .
I thought ay wele ; how it sholde be .
Menne shold not knowe ; of goddis priuite
Ya blessed be alwaye ; a lewde man .
That nought but oonly his bileve can
So ferd anothre clerke ; with Astronomie
He walked in the feldis ; for to prye .
Vpoıı̄un the sterres ; what there shulde be falle
Tille he was in a marle pitt I falle .
He sawe not that ; but yet be seynt Thomas
Me reweth sore ; of hende Nicholas
He shalbe rated ; of his studying
If that I may ; be Ihus ; heuen kyng
Gete me a staf ; that I may vnder spore
Whil that thou Robyn ; hevest vp the dore
He shalle oute of his studying as I gesse
And to the chambre dore / he gan hym dresse
His knave was a strong carle ; for the nones .
And by the haspe he have it vp at ones
In to the floure ; the dore fille anoıı̄un
This Nicholas aye as stille sat as any stoıı̄un
And ever gaped vpwarde ; in the eyre
This Carpenter had went he were in dispeyre
And hent hym by the shuldres mightly
And shoke hym harde ; and cryed spitouslye
What Nicholas howe . loke adoun
A wake and thinke on cristes passioıı̄un
I crowche the from Elves and from wightis
Therwᵗith the nightspell ; he seide anon rightes
On foure halues ; and on the house abowte
And on the thressholde on the dore wᵗithowte
Ihesu crist ; and seint Benedict
Blis this hows ; from euerye wikked wight
For the nightes verye ; the white pater noster
Here we nestowe ; thou seint Peter suster
And at the laste this hende Nicholas
Gan forto sike sore ; and seid allas
Shall alle the worlde ; eftsones nowe
This Carpenter answered ; what seist thou
What thynke on god as we doon men þᵗat swynke
This Nicholas answered fetche me drynke .
And after wille I speke in priuite
Of certayne thyng ; that toucheth the and me
I wille telle it ; noon othir man certayne
This Carpenter goth doun and cometh ageyne
And brought of myghty Ale a large quart
And brought of myghty ale a large quart
And whan that eche of hem had dronken his part
This Nicholas ; his dore faste shette
And downe be the Carpenter ; hym he sett
And seid Iohn ; myn Oost leve and dere
Thou shalt vpon thy trouthe ; swere me here .
That to no wight ; þᵘ shalt this counseile wreye .
For it is cristes cownseile ; that I seye
And yf þᵘ telle it ; man thou art for lore
For this vengeaunce ; thou shalt have therfore
That yf thou wreie me ; thou shalt be wood .
Naye criste for bede ; it / for his holy blood .
Qd tho this sely man ; / I am no labbe
Ne though ; I seye I am not leef to gabbe
Seye what thou wilt ; I shalle it never telle
To childe ne wyf ; be hym that harowed helle
Now Iohn qd Nicholas ; I wille not lye .
I haue I founden ; in myn Astrologie
As I haue loked ; in the moone bright
That nowe a mondaye next a quarter night
Shall falle a reyne ; that so wilde and wood .
That half soo . gret ; was Noe. his flood .
This worlde he seide . lesse than an oure .
Shall alle be dreynt ; so hidous is the shoure
Thus shall mankynde ; drenche and lese here lif
This Carpenter answered ; allas my wif
And shalle she drenche ; allas myn Alysoıı̄un .
For sorowe of this ; he felle almoste adoun
And seide is there no ; remedye ; in this caas .
Why yis there forgode ; qd hende Nicholas
If thowe wille werchen ; after thyn ownelore ⁊and reed .
Þᵘ mayste not werken ; after thyn owne hede
For thus seythe Salamon ; that is full trewe
Warke all be cownseill ; and þᵘ shalt not rewe
And yf thou wille werken wele be good counseill
I vndirtake wᵗithoute maste or seile
And yit shall I have hir ; and the ⁊and me .
Hast thou not herd ; howe saved was Noe.
Whan that oure lorde ; had warned hym beforn
That alle the water ; with water shold be lorn
Yis qd this Carpenter ; full yore agoo .
Hast nought herd . qd Nicholas alsoo .
The sorowe of Noe. wᵗith his felisshippe
Or that he myght . gete his wif to shippe
Hym hadde lever . I dare wele vndirtake
At thilke tyme ; than alle his wetheres blake
That she had a shippe hir self allone
And therfor wost þᵘ ; what is best to doon
This axeth haste ; and of hastif thing
Menne may not preche ; ne make tarying
A noon . goo gete vs faste ; in to this Inne
A knedyng . trowe ; or elles a kemelyne
For eche of vs ; but loke that they be large
In whiche men mow swymme as in a barge
And han there vetailes ; suffisaunt
But for a day ; fye on the remenaunt
The water shall aslake ; and gon aweye .
A bowte pryme . vpon the next daye
But Robyn may not wete of this thy knave
Ne eke thy maide gille ; I may not save
Axe not why ; for though thou axe me .
I wille not tellen ; goddes pryuite .
Suffiseth the withoute ; thy wittes madde .
To have as gret a grace ; as Noe hadde
Thy wif shall I wele saven ; owte of dowte
Go nowe thy weye ; and spede the there abowte
But whan þᵘ haste ; for hir. the . and me .
I geten vs . this knedyng ; tubbes thre .
Thanne shallt þᵘ hang ; hem ; in the roof full hye
That noman of oure purveaunce aspye
And whan þᵘ thus hast doon ; as I have seide
And hast oure vetaile ; faire in hem laide
And eke an Axe ; to smyte the corde ; atwoo
Whan that the water comethe ; that we may goo
And breke an hole ; high vpoıı̄un the gable
Vnto the gardynward ; over the stable
That we may frelye passen ; forthe oure weie waye
Than shalt thou ; swymme ; as mery I vndertake
As dothe the white dofe ; aftir his drake .
Than wille I clepe ; how Alyson how Iohn .
Be mery ; for the flood /; wille passe anoon
Than wilt þᵘ seyne /; heile Maister Nicholay
Good morowe I se wele . for it is daye .
And than shall we ben lordes alle oure lyf
Of alle the world ; as Noe ; and his wyf
But that oo thyng I warne full right
Be wele avised /; on that ilke night
That we ben entred ; in to the shippes boord .
That noōn of vs ; speke not oo woord
Ne clepe ne crye . but ben in his prayer
For it is goddes owne heste dere .
Thy wif and thou . mote hangen fer atwynne
For that bitwixe yow . shalbe no synne
No more in lokyng ; than there shall in dede
This ordenaunce ; is saide so god me spede .
To morowe at night ; whan men ben all in slepe /.
And than nowe we feyne ; fare wele firs ⁊and have good day
In oure knedynges tubbes wille we crepe .
And sitten there / abiding goddes grace
Go now theye weye ; I have no lenger space
To make of this ; no lenger sermonnyng
Men seyne thus sende the wise ⁊and sey nothing
Thou art so wise it nedith not the to teche
Goo saf oure lyf ; and that I the beseche
This sely Carpenter ; gothe forthe his weye
Full ofte he seid allas ; and welaweye .
And to his wif he tolde his pⁱriuite
And she was ware ; and knewe it bett than he
What alle this queynte cast was for to seie
But neuthelesse ; she farid as she wolde deye
And seid allas ; go forthe thy weye anoıı̄un .
Helpe vs to escape ; or we ben dede echoıı̄un .
I am thy trewe wedded wyf
Go dere spouse ; and helpe to save oure lyf
Lo which a gret thyng ; is full affecciou
Men ; maye die ; of ymaginaciou
So depe maye impressiou be take
This sely Carpenter ; beginneth quake .
Hym thinketh verrily ; that he may see
Noes flood . walking ; as the see .
To drenchen Alisou ; his honye dere .
He wepyth ⁊and wayleth ; she makyth sory chere
He syketh ; with many a full sory swough
And gothe and getith hym a kneding trough
And after a tubbe ; and a kymlyn
And pryuely ; hent sent hem to hys Inne
And henge hem in the roof in priuite
His owne hand ; he made ladders thre
To clymben by the ronges ; and by the stalkes
Vnto the tubbes. hangyng in the balkes .
And hem vetailled ; bothe trough and tubbe .
Wᵗith breed and chese ; and good ale in a Iubbe
Suffysing right I nowe ; as for a daye
But or that he had made ; alle this arraye
He sente his knave / and his wenche also
Vpon his nede ; to london for to goo .
And on the mondaye ; whan it drowe to night
He shitte his dore ; wᵗithoute candell light
And dressed alle thyng ; that it sholde so be
And shortly clomben vp alle thre
They sitten stille ; wele a furlong weye
Now Pater noster now clum ; seid Nicholay
And clum seide Iohn ; and clum ; seide Alysoıı̄un
This Carpenter seide his devocioıı̄un
And stille he sitte ; and bidde his prayere
Awaityng . on the reyne ; yf he it here .
The dethe slepe ; for wery besinesse
Fille on this Carpenter right as I gesse
Abowte curfew tyme ; or litle more
For trauaileth of his goste ; he groneth sore
And efte he routeth ; for his hede mys laye
Downe of the laddre ; stalketh Nicholay
And Alysoıı̄un full softe doun she spedde
Wᵗithoute wordes moo ; they goon to bedde .
There as the Carpenter is wonte to lye .
There was the revell ; and the melodye
And thus lieth Alisoıı̄un and Nicholas
In besynesse of myrthe ; and of solas
Tille at the belle of lawdes gan to rynge
And Freris ; in the chaunsell gon synge
This parissh clerke ; this Amerous Absoloıı̄un
That is for love ; alweye so woo begoon
Vpoıı̄un the mondaye ; was at Osenaye .
With company hym to disport and playe .
And axed vpon caas a cloistrer
Full priuily . aftir Iohn . the carpenter
And he drowe him a part oute of the chirche
And seid I not I saw hym not here werche
Sithe Satirday I trowe that he be went
For tymber there owre Abbot hath hym sent
For he is wonte for tymber for to goo .
And dwellen at the graunge ; a day or too
Or elles he is at his hous certeyne .
Where that he be cam ; sothly I can not seyne
This Absoloıı̄un ; full ioly was and light
⁊and thought nowe is tyme ; to wake alle night
For sikerly . I saw hym not stering
A bowten his dore ; syn daye gan to spryng
So mote I thryve I shalle at the cokkes crowe
Full priuely knokken at his wyndowe
That stant full lowe ; vnder his boures wall
To Alisoıı̄un now I wille tellen all
My longyng love ; for yit I shall not mysse
Than at the leste wey ; I shall hir kisse
Som mane comforte shall I have parfaye
My mouthe hath itched alle this long daye
That is a signe of kissyng at the leste
That alle me mente that I was at a feste
I wille therfor go slepe an oure . or tweye
Than alle the night ; wille I rage ⁊and pleye .
Whan that the first kok ; hath crowen anoıı̄un
Vp rist this iolye lover Absoloıı̄un
And hym arraieth gaye at point deuyse
But furste he cheweth ; graynes and licorise
To smellen soote ; or he had kempt his here
Vnder his tonge ; A trewe love he bere
For therby wende ; he ; to be gracious
He rometh ; vnto the ; Carpenters hows
And stille he stonde ; vnder the shoppe windowe
Vnto his brest it raught ; it was soo lowe
And softe he coughed ; wᵗith a semy sowne
What do ye honycombe ; swete Alysou .
My faire bird my swete synamome
A waketh lemman ; and speke to me
Full litle thinken ye . vpon my woo
That for youre love swete I there I goo
No wonder is ; though I swelt or swete
I morne as dothe ; the lambe aftir the tete
I wis lemman I have soch love longyng
That like a turtille ; trew is my moᵘurnyng
I may not ete ; nomore than a maide
Go fro my window ; Iak foole she saide .
So helpe me god ; it wille not be compame
I love another ; and elles I were to blame
Wele bet than the ; be Ihıı̄un Absoloıı̄un
Go forthe they weye ; or I wille cast a stoıı̄un
And lete me slepe . a twenty devilwaye
Allas qd Absoloıı̄un ; and welewaye
That true love was evir ; so eville be sette
Than kysse me ; syn it wil be noo bette
For Ihus love ; and for the love of me
Wilt þᵘ than . go thy waye ; qd she .
Ye certes lemman ; qd this Absolon
Than make the redy ; qd she ; I come a non
This absoloıı̄un . down sett hym on his knees .
And seid I am a lorde at alle degrees
For aftir this I hope there cometh more
Lemman thy grace . and swete bird thyn ore
The window . she vndothe ; and that in haste
Have do . qd she ; come of and spede the faste
Lest that oure neighboᵘurs / the aspie
This Absoloıı̄un gan wipe his mouthe full drye
Derke was the night ; as pitche or cole
And at the wyndow ; owte she put hir hole
And Absoloıı̄un . he fille no bett nor wers
But wᵗith his mowthe. he kissed hir naked ars
Full savoᵃlye . or he were ware of this
A bakke he stirte ; and thought it was a mys
For wele he wiste ; a womman had no berde
He felt a thyng . alle rough ⁊and long I herede
And seid fy allas ; what have I doo
Te he qd she ; and clappid the window too
Absoloıı̄un gothe forthe a sorye paas
A berde a berde seide hende Nicholas .
By goddes corpus ; this gothe faire and wele
This selye Absoloıı̄un ; herde it euery dele
And on his lippe ; he gan for anger byte .
And to hym self he said I shalle the quyte
Who rubbeth who froteth ; now his lippes
With dust wᵗith sonde ; wᵗith strawe ; wᵗith clothe ; wᵗith chippes .
But Absoloıı̄un he seith full often allas
My sowle I be take to Sathanas ;
But me were levir ; than alle this town qd he
Of this dispite ; wroken for to be
Allas qd he allas I ne had I bleynte
His hote love was colde and all I queynte
For fro the tyme ; he had kist hir ars
Of ꝑparamours love ; he sett not a kers
For he was helid ; of his maladie
Full ofte ꝐParamoᵘs ; he gan defye
And wepith as dothe a childe that is bete
A softe paas ; he went owre the strete
Vnto a smythe ; men clepid hym Gerveys
That in his forge ; smethied hors harneys
He sharpeth share ; and culter besilye
This Absoloıı̄un ; knokketh full esily
And seide vnto Gerueys ⁊and that a noıı̄un
What art thou ; it am I Absoloıı̄un
What Absolon ; what cristes swete tree .
Why rise ye soo rathe ; aye benedicite
What eileth you ; som gay girle ; god it woot
Hath brought you thus ; on the vyritoot
Be seint note ; ye woot wele what I mene
This Absoloıı̄un . ne rought not a bene
Of his playe ; no worde ageyn he gaf
He had more tough . on his distaf
Than Gerueys knew . and seid freend so dere
This hoot culter ; in the chymeny here
As lenede it me . I have therwᵗith to done
I wille bryng it ageyne ; fulle sone .
Gerueys answered ; certes were it golde
Or in a poke ; nobles alle vntolde
Þᵘ it shall haue as I am trewe smythe
Eye cristes foo ; what wille ye do therwᵗith
Therof qd Absoloıı̄un . be as be maye .
I shalle wele tellen the / to morowe daye
And caught the culter ; by the brode stele
Full softe oute at the dore . he gan stele
And went on to the Carpenters walle
He coughed furst ; and knokked ther wᵗithalle
Vpon the wyndowe . right as he did ere
This Alison answered who is there
That knokketh soo I warant it a thef
Why nay qd he ; god woot my swete lef
I am thy Absoloıı̄un . and thy derlyng
Of gold qd he . I have the brought a ryng
My moder yave it me ; so god me save
Full fyne it is ; and therto wele I grave
This wille I yeuen the ; yf þᵘ me kisse
Nicholas was risen ; for to pisse
And thought he wolde ; amenden all the iape
He shuld kisse his ars ; or that he scape
And vp with the window did he hastilye
And oute his ers . he putt priuelye
Ouer the buttok ; to the haunche boıı̄un
And therwᵗith spake this clerke this Absoloıı̄un
Speke swete bird ; I woot not where þᵘ art
This Nicholas anoıı̄un lete fle A farte
As gret as it had be ; a thonder dente
With that stroke ; he was almoste I blent
And he was redy ; with his yren hote
And Nicholas in the ars he smote
Of gothe the skynne ; an handbrede aboute
The hoot culter brennyd so his towte
And for the smert ; he wende for to deye
As he were wood ; for woo he gan to deye crie
Helpe water water ; helpe for goddes herte
This Carpenter owte of his slomber sterte
And herd on cryen water as he were wood
And thought allas ; now cometh Nowellis flood
And sett hym vp ; wᵗithoute woordꝭes moo .
And wᵗith an axe ; he smoot the corde A too .
And down gothe alle . he fonde neither to selle
Bred ne Ale ; tille he come to the selle
Vpoıı̄un the floure ; and there aswowne he laye .
Vp stirte hir Alysoıı̄un and Nicholay
And cried oute ; and harrow in the strete
The neighboᵘurs bothe smale and grete
I ronnen for to gawren ; on this man
That a swowne laye . bothe pale and wan
For that falle . hathe euyn broken his arme
But stonde he muste . vnto his owne harme
For whan he spake ; anoıı̄un . was he bore downe .
With hynde Nicholas and Alisoıı̄un
They tolde euery man ; that he was wood .
He was a gast so . of Nowellis flood.
Thorugh fantasye ; that of his vanite
He had I gete hym ; knedyng tubbes thre
And had hem hanged ; in the roof a bove
And that he prayed hym ; for goddes love .
To sitten in the roof ; for companye .
The folke gan laughen ; at his fantasye
And to the roof . they kiken . and they gapēn
And torned all his ernest ; to A iape
For whatso this Carpenter answered
It was for nought / noman his resou herd
Withe othes gret ; he was so sore swore a down
That he was holden ; wood ; in alle the town
For every clerke ; anoıı̄un ; right helde wtother
And seid the man is wood ; my leve brother
And euery wight . gan lawghen at this strif
Thus swyved was ; the Carpenters wyf
For alle his kepyng ; and ialousye
And Absolōn hath kissed hir nethir eye
And Nicholas is scalded ; in his towte
This tale is doon ; and god save alle the route
Here endith the Mellers tale of the Reve
And here begynneth the Prolog of þᵉ Reves tale
Whan folke han laughen at this nyce caas
Of Absolon̄ and hende Nicholas
Diuerse folke diủerslye they seide
But for the more part they lough and pleide
Ne at this tale I saw noman hym greve
But it were only Oswolde the Reve
Be cawse he was of Carpenters crafte
A litle Ire in his herte lafte
He gan to grucche and blamed it A lyte
So thyk qduod he full wele coude I yow quyte
With bleryng of a proude Mellers eye
Yf that me liste to speke of ribawdrye
But yk am olde me list no pleye for age
Grasse tyme is doon · my foder is forage
This white toppe writeth my olde yeres
Myn hert is also mowled as myn̄ here
But I fare as dothe an open ars
That ilke frute / is ever longer the wars
Tille it be roten / in mullok or in stree
We olde men̄ I drede so fare wee
Tille we be roten / can we not be ripe
We hoppen alweye whil the world will pipe
For in oure wille there stiketh alweye a naile
To have an hore here / and a likerous taile
As hath a leek / for though a might be goon
Oure wille desireth foly / alle in oon
For whan̄ we may not don̄ / than will we speken̄
Yit in oure asshen olde is fire I reken
Foure gledes han̄ we which I shal devyse
Avauntyng lieng / Anger / covetise
Theis foure sperkels / longyng to the elde
Oure olde lemes mow wele ben vnwelde
But will ne shall not failen that is soothe
And yit I haue alwey a coltes tothe
As many a yere as it passed henne
Syn that my lif / began̄ to renne
For sikerlye whan I was born̄ anon̄
Dethe drough the tappe of lif ⁊and lete it goon
And euer sithen̄ hath soo the tappe I ronne
Tille almost empty is the tonne
The streem of lif now droppith on the chynbe
The sely tong may wele ringe and chymbe
Of wretchidnesse / that passid is full yore
With olde folke saf dotage is nomore
Whan̄ that oure Oost / had herd this sermonyng
He gan to speken / as lordlye as a kyn
He seide what amownteth alle this witte
What shall we speke alday of holy writte
The deuel made a Reve for to preche
Or of a sowter a Shipman̄ or a leche
Seye forthe thy tale / and tary nought the tyme
Lo depford and it is alwey pⁱrime
Lo Grenewich that many a shrewe is yn
It were alle tyme thy tale for to begynne
Nowe sirs qduod this Oswolde / the Reve
I pray yow alle / ye nought you greve
Though I answer and somwhat set his houfe
For levefull is wᵗith force for of schoufe
This dronken meller / hathe tolde vs here
How that he be he be giled was a Carpenter
Paraventure in skorn̄ for I am oon̄
And by youre leve I shall hym quyte anoon̄
Right in his cherles termes wille I spek
I prey to god / his nekke mote to breke
He can wele in myn eye seen a stalke
But in his owne he can not seen a balke
Here endith the Prolog of the Reve
And here begynneth his tale folwynge
AT Trompington not fer from Cambrige
There goth a brook ⁊and oủere þᵗat a brigge
Vpon the which brook there stant a melle
And this is verrey sothe that I you telle
A mellere was there dwellyng many a daye
As any Pecok he was proude and gaye
Pipen he cowde and fisshen̄ and nettes bete
And turne cuppes / and wele wrestele and shete
And by his belt / he bare a longe panade
And of a swerd full trenchᵃunt was the blade
A Iolye popper / bare he in his powche
There was noman̄ for perell durst hym towche
A Shefeld thwytell bare he in his hose
Round was his face / and cammed was his nose
As pilled as an Ape was his skulle
He was at market better than̄ at fulle
There was no wight þᵗat durst hond on hym legge
But he were sure / a noon̄ he shuld abegge
A thef he was forsothe of corne and mele
And that a slye and an vsant for to stele
His name was hote Deynous symkyn
A wif he had come of noble kynne
The ꝑperson̄ of the town̄ / hir fader was
With hir he yaf full many a panne of bras
For that Symkyn̄ sholde in his blood allie
She was I fostred / in a Nonnerye
For Symken wolde no wif as he saide
But she were wele I norisshed and a maide
To saven his estat of yomanrye
And she was prowde and as pert as a pye
A full faire sight was it vpon̄ hem twoo
On halidaies beforn̄ hir wold he goo
Wᵗith his tipet wounden / abowte his hede
And she cam after / in a gite of red
And symkyn had hosen / of the same
There durst no wight / clepen hir but dame
Was noon so hardy / that went so by the weye
That wᵗith hir durst rage / or ones pleye
But yf he wolde be slayn̄ of synkyn̄ symkyn
With knif or wᵗith panade or wᵗith boydekyn̄
For ielous folke / ben perlous euer moo
Algate they wolde / her wyfes wenden soo
And eke for she was somdele smoterliche
She was as digne / as water in a dyche
As full of hoker / and of bismare
Hir thought that a lady shold hir spare
What for hir kynrede / and for hir nortelrie
That she had lerned / in the Nonnerye
A doughter had theye / betwix hem twoo
Of twenty yere // wᵗithoute any moo // of agewᵗithoute any mooof age wᵗithoute any moo
Savyng a childe / that was of half yere age
In cradille it laye / and was propir page
This wenche thikke / and wele I growen was
Wᵗith camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
Wᵗith buttokkꝭes brood wᵗith rounde bresetes and hye
But right faire was here heere I wil not lye
The person̄ of the town̄ / for she was faire
In purpoos was / to maken hir his heire
Bothe of his catelle and also his mesuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpose was to be stowe hir hye
Vnto som̄ worthy blood / of Auncetrye
For holy chirches good moot be dispendid
On holy chirche / that is descended
Therfor he wolde his holyblood honoᵘur
Though that holy chiche shold devoᵘur
Gret soken hath this myller owte of dowte

div.l: And namliche ther was a greet Collage
Men clepyd it the Soler Halle at Cambrigge
There was hir whete / and eke hir malt I groıı̄und
And on a daye it happed / in a stounde
Syke laye the Manciple / on a maladie
Men wende wiselye / that he shuld deye
For the which the meller stale bothe mele ⁊and corne
An hundred tyme / more than̄ he did beforne
For there beforne / he stale but curteslye
But now he was a theef outeragiouslye
For which the wardeyne / chid and made fare
But therof sett the meller not half a tare
He craked bosted and swore / it was not soo
Than̄ were there yong scolers twoo
That dwelten / in the halle of which I seye
Testif they were / and lusty for to pleye
And oonly for hir myrthe and reuelrye
Vpon̄ the daye / besily they crie
To yeve leve to hym but a litle stounde
To go to melle / and seen hir corn̄ I grounde
And hardly they durst / leye hir nekke
The meller shold not stele from hēm half a pekke
Of corn̄ ne be sleight ne be force hem reve
And at the laste / the wardeyne yaf hem leve
Iohn hight the oon̄ / and Aleyn̄ hight the other
Of on̄ town̄ were they borne þᵗat hight Strother
Fer in the Northe I can̄ not telle where
This Aleyn̄ maketh alle redy his gere
And on an hors / the sak he cast a noon̄
Forthe gothe Aleyne the clerke and also Iohn
With good swerdes ⁊and bokelers be hir sides
Iohn knew the weye / hym nedith no gides
And at the mylne the sak a downe he laithe
Aleyn̄ spak furst / all heile Symond in faithe
How fares thy faire doughter and thy wyf
Aleyn̄ welcome qduod Symkyn / be my lif
And Iohn also how nowe what do ye here
Be god qduod John Symond nede ne nede hath no pere
Hym behoueth serue hym self þᵗat hath no swayn̄
Or elles he is a foole / as clerkes seyne
Oure manciple / I hope he wilbe dede
Swa werkes hym aye the wynges in his hede
And therfor I is I come / and eke Aleyn̄
To grynde oure corne and carie it home ageyn̄
I pray you spede vs hens in that ye maye
It shalbe doon / qduod Symkyn̄ be my faye
What will ye doo whil it is in hande
Be god right be thyn hoper will I stande
Qduod Iohn and se how gates / the corne goth yn
Yit sawe I nevir / be my Fader kyn̄
How that the hoper wagges tille and fra
Aleyn̄ seid Iohn wilt þᵘou swa
Than wille I be benethe be my crown̄
And se how gates / the mele come adown̄
In to the trough / that shalbe my disporte
Qduod Iohn in faithe I may be of youre soorte
I is as ille a meller as are ye
This miller smyled / of hir nycite
And thought all this is not doon bᵗut for a wile
They wene that noman̄ / maye them begil
But be my thryfte yit shall I blere here eye
For alle the sleight / in here Philosophie
The more queynte that þᵉ clerkes make
The more wille I stele whan̄ I take
In stede of floure / yit wulle I yeve hem bren̄
The grettest clerkes / be not wisest menne
As whilom to the wolf / thus spake the mare
Of alle hir arte / counte I not a tare
Oute of the dore / he gothe full priuelye
Whan that he saugh his tyme softelye
He loketh vp and down̄ / tille that he hath founde
The clerkes hors / there as it stood I bounde
Behinde the melle vnder a leuefsell
And to the hors he gothe hym / faire ⁊and wele
He striped of the bridelle right anon̄
And whan the hors was loos he gynneth gon
Toward the Fenne there wilde mares renne
And forthe wᵗith we he thorugh thikke ⁊and thenne
This miller gothe ageyne / noo wurd he saide
But dothe his note and wᵗith thes clerkes plaide
Tille that hir corn was faire and wele I grounde
And whan̄ the mele is sakked and I bounde
This Iohn gothe oute and fyndeth his hors aweye
And gan to crye harrow and wele aweye
Oure hors is loost Aleyn̄ for goddes banys
Step vp thy feet come of alle at onys
Allas oure wardeyne hath his palfrey lorne
This Aleyn̄ all forgat bothe mele and corne
Alle was owte of his mynde his husbondrye
What whilke weye is he go he gan̄ crye
The wif cam lepyng Inward at a renne
She seid allas youre hors gothe to the Fenne
With wilde mares / as fast as he may goo
Vnthanke come to his hande / þᵗat bonde hym soo
And he that better / sholde have knyt the reyne
Allas qduod Iohn Aleyn / for crystes peyne
Leye down̄ thy swerd and I will myn alswa
I is full swyfte god wot as any ra
By goddes herte / he shall nat scape vs baothebothebathe
Why ne had þᵘou /putte the caple / in the lathe
Il haile be god Aleyn̄ / þᵘou is a fonne
This sely clerkes / han full fast I ronne
Toward the Fen̄ / bothe Aleyn̄ and eke Iohn
And whan̄ the myller sauh þᵗat they were goon̄
Half a busshell of hir floure / he hath take
And bad his wyf go g g knede it in a cake
And seid I trowe the clerkes weren a ferde
Yit can a myller / make a clerkes beerd
For alle hir arte yit lete hem go hir weie
Lo where he gothe / ye lete the children pleie
Theye geten hym not so lightly be my crown̄
This sely myller clerkes myllerclerkes // renneth vp and down̄
With kepe kepe stand stand iossa wardere
Ga whistil thou / and I shall kepe hym here
But shortly tille it was verrey night
They coude not gete hȳm though they diden all here myght
Hir caple catche / it ranne aweye so faste
Tille in a Diche / they caught hȳm at þᵉ last
Werye and wete as / beest in the reyne
Cometh sely Iohn / and with hym Aleyne
Allas qduod Iohn / the daye that I was borne
Now are we dreven̄ / tille hevyng ⁊and tille scorn̄
Oure corne is stole / men wille vs fooles calle
Bothe the wardeyn̄ / and oure felawes alle
And namly the miller welawey
Thus pleyneth Iohn / as he gothe be the wey
Toward the melle / and bayard in his hande
The miller syttyng be the Fyre he fande
For it was night ⁊and furthermore they thought
But for the love of god / they him be sought
Of herberwe and of ease / as for ther peny
The meller seid ageyne / yf ther be any
Suche as it is / ye shall have youre part
Myn̄ house is streight / but ye han̄ lerned art
Ye can̄ be argument / make a place
A myle brood / of twenty foot of space
Lat se now / yf this place may suffice
Or make it room / wᵗith speche as is youre gyse
Now Symond seid this Iohn be seynt Cutberd
Ay is þᵘou merye / and that is faire answered
I haue herd seye / þᵗat men shold take of two thyngꝭes
Swylke as he fynt / ar he shall take swilk as he bryngꝭes
But specially I pray the Oost dere
Gete vs som mete ⁊and drynke ⁊and make vs som̄ good cheere
And we wille paien̄ truly at the full
Wᵗith empty hondes men may noon̄ hawkes tulle
Lo here our silủere / redy for to spende
This meller to the town̄ / his dought̉er sende
For Ale and brede / and rosted hem a goos
And bond hir hors / it shold nomore go loos
And in his owne chamber / he made a bedde
With shetes ⁊and wᵗith shalons / faire I spreed
Nought from his owne bed / ten foot or twelue
His doughter had a bedde / albe hir selue
Right in the same chambre by and by
It myght be no bett / and the cause why
There was no more romer herberwe in þᵉ place
Hem sowpen and speken them to solace
And dronken eủere strong Ale / at the beste
A bowte mydnight wente they to reste
Wele hath this meller vernisshed his hede
Full pale he was / for dronken ⁊and not red
He yexithe and he speketh / thorugh þᵉ nose
As he ware on the quake / or on the pose
To bedde he gothe / ⁊and wᵗith hym gothe his wif
As any Iay he light was an as iolyf
So was hir ioly whistle wele I wete
The cradyll at here beddes feet is I sett
To rokken and to yeve hir childe sowke
And whan that dronken was all in the crowke
To bedde went the dought̉er / right a noon̄
To bedde gothe Aleyn̄ / and also Iohn
There is nomore / hym nedeth no dwale
This meller hath so wysely bibbed Ale
That as an hors he snortethe / in his slepe
Ne of his tayle be hynde / he took no kep
His wyf bare hym a burdon̄ full strong
Men myghten here routyng a furlong
The wenche routeth eke ꝑpar companye
Aleyn̄ the clerke / that herd this melodie
He powked Iohn / and seid slepist thou
Hardest þᵘou evir sike a song / or nowe

div.l: A litle iape / that fille in oure citee
Oure oost answerid / and seid I graunt the
Now telle on Roger / looke þᵗat it be good
For many a Pasty / hast þᵘou leten blood
And many a Iakke of Dover þᵘou hast hast sold
That hath be twies hoot and twies colde
Of many a Pilgrym / hast þᵘou cristes curs
For of thy persely / yit fare they the wers
That they han eten wᵗith the stubbel goos
For in thy shoppe / there is many a flie loos
Now telle on̄ gentill Roger be thyn name
But yit I prey the be not wrothe for game
A man say full sothe / in game and playe
Þᵘou seist full sothe / qduod Roger be my faye
But sothe play quade / play as þᵉ flemyng saith
And therfor herry baillif / be thy faithe
Be þᵘou not wrothe / or we departen here
Though that my tale / be of an hostillere
But neủertheles I wille tellen it yitte
But or we parte I wis þᵘou shalt be quytte
And there with all / he lough and made chere
And seid his tale / as ye shall after here
Here endith the Prolog of the Cooke
And here begynneth his tale folwyng
A Prentys whilom dwellid īn our͗e cite
And of a craft of vitaillers was he
Gailard he was as goldfinche in þᵉ shawe
Brown̄ as the berye / a propir short felaw
With lokkes blake I kempt full fetisly
Daunce he cowde / so wele and Iolily
That he was cleped / Perkyn reveloᵘur
He was as full of love ꝑparamoᵘur
As is the hyve / full of hony swete
Wele was the wenche wᵗith hym myght mete
At euery bridall he wold syng and hoppe
He loved bet the tauerne / than̄ the shoppe
For whan̄ any ryding / was there in Chepe
Out of the shoppe / thider wolde he lepe
Till that he had / all the sight I seyn
And daunced wele / wolde he not come a geyn̄
And gadred hym a meyny of his sort
To hoppe and syng / and make soche disport
And there they settyn steven for to mete
To pleyen at the dys / in soche a strete
For īn the town̄ / nas there no prentys
That fairer cowde cast a peire of dys
Than Perkyn cowde and ther to he was free
Of his dispense / in place of priuite
That fond his maister wele in his chaffare
For often tyme / he fond his box full bare
For sikirly / a prentys reueloᵘur
That haunteth dys Ryot or ꝑparamoᵘur
His maister shall it / in his shoppe abeye
All have he no part of his menstralcye
For yift and ryot / they ben conuertible
All can he pleye / on Giterne and Rubible
Reuell and trouthe / is in a lowe Degre
They ben full wroth all day / as men may see
This ioly prentyse wᵗith his maister bode
Tille he were nigh out of his prentys hode
Alle were he snybbed / bothe erthly erlyerthlyerly ⁊and late
And somtyme ledde wᵗith revell to Newgate.
But at the last / his maister hym bethought
Vpon̄ a daye whan he his paper sought
Of a prouerbe / that seith this same word
Well bet is roten appill / oute of the hoord
Than that it roteth / all the remenᵃaunt
So farith it by a riotous seruᵃaunt
It is full lasse harme / to late it pase
Than̄ he shende alle the seruᵃauntes in the place
Therfor his maister / yaf hym a quetaunce
And bad hym go / with sorow and myschaıı̄unce
And thus this Ioly prentys / had his leve
Nowe late hym ryot / all the night or leve
For there is no theef / wᵗithoute a lowken̄
That helpith hym / to wasten ⁊and to sowken̄
Of that he bribe can / or borowe maye
A non̄ he sent his bed / and his array
Vnto a Cōmwper / of his owne sorte
That loved dyse / and reuell and disporte
And had a wyf / that helde for contenᵃaunce
A shoppe and swyved for hir sustenᵃaunce

div.l: (base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle

(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name

(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf

(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo

(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say

div.l: (base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas

div.l: (base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled

(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise

(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas

(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se

div.l: (base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors

(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme

(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
