And here begynneth . another prolog for þᵉ same pardoner .
LOrdynges . qd he in chirches when I preche
I peyne me to have an hawnteyn speche
div.fw: . a . nother prolog of the Pardoner .
div.l: I ryng it oute . / as round . as gothe A belle
For I can alle be roote . / that I telle
My terme is alweye oon . / and euer was
First I pronounce . / whense that I come
And then my bulles . / shew I alle and some .
Oure liege lordes . / is my patent
That shewe I firste . / my body to warent
That no . man . be so bolde . ne prest nor clerke
Me to distourbe . / for cristes holy werke
And after that . / telle I forthe my tales .
Bulles . of popes . / and of Cardinales
Of Patriarkes . / and busshopes I shewe
And in latyn . I speke . a wordes fewe .
To saffren with my predicacioıı̄un
And for to stere . men to deuocioıı̄un .
Then shewe I forthe . / my long cristall stones
I crammed full of clowtes . / and of bones .
Relekes . theye ben w as wene theye echon
Then haue I in latoıı̄un . / A shulder bone .
Whiche that was . vpon . holye Iewes shepe
Good men seye I . / taketh of my wordys kepe
If that this . bon . be wasshe . / in any . welle .
Yf Cowe . or calf . / shepe . or Oxe . swelle .
That any worme . hath I ete . or I stonge
Touche he is this . bon . / A noōn he schalbe sounde .
And yit also . of furthermore .
Of pokkes . and of scabbes . / and of euery sore .
Shalle euery sheep . be hoole / that of this welle
Drinketh . a . draught . / and take kepe what I telle
Wulle euery wight . / or that the cok hym crowethe .
And for to do . thyng that hym owethe
Fastyng drinke of this welle . A . draught
And ilke holy iewe . / oure eldres vs taught
His bestis . and his store . / shalle multiplie
And sirs also . it helithe Ielousie
And theye . A man be falle in ielouse rage
Lette make with this water . his potage
And neuer shalle he more . / his wyf mystruste
Theye he the sothe A defaute . be here wiste
Alle had she taken . prestis . tweyne . or three .
Here is a Meteyne . eke . ye maye see
He that his honde . wille put in that Metayne
He shall haue . multiplying . / of his grayne
Whan he hathe sowen . / be it whete . or Otes
So that of pens . geve or elles of grotes
And men . and wōmmen . / oo . thyng warne I you .
Yf any wight . be in this chirche nowe
That hathe don synne horrible . / that he
Dare not for shame . / shreuen be .
Or any womman . / be so . yong or olde
That hath I made . hir husbond . Cokeolde .
Soche folke have no power . / ne grace
To offre to my Relikes . / in this place
And whoso fynde hem . out . of soche blame
Theye wole come vp . / and offre in goddis name
And I assoile hem . / be the auctorite
Soche as by bulle . / was graunted me
Be this gaude haue I wonne euery yeer
Be this gaude . / haue I wonne euery yere .
An hundred marke . / sethens I was pardonere .
I stande I like . A . clerke . / in many A . pulpet
And shewe lewde peple . / and down theye sitte
I preche so as . ye haue . herde before
And telle an . hundred . iapes more
Thanne peyne I me . to stretche forthe my necke
And Erst and west . on the peple I bekke .
As a dowe dothe . / sitting vpon A . berne .
Myn hondes . and my tonge / gon so yerne
That it is ioye . / to see my besynesse
Of auarice . and soche othre cursidnesse
Is alle my prechyng . to make hem free
To yeue hir . pens . and namely vnto me
For myn entent nys nought . / but for to wynne
And nothyng for correccioıı̄un . / of synne
I rekke neuer . whan theye ben beried
Thouȝ that hir sowles goon . A . blak beried .
For certes many a / . predicacioıı̄un
Sowneth ofte tyme . / of yvell entencioıı̄un
Som for plesaunce of folke / or for flaterye .
To ben avaunced . / by ypocrisye
Some for veynglorie . / and some for hate .
For when I dar not othir wise debate
Then wille I stynge hem . / wᵗith my tonge smerte .
In prechyng . / so that he shalle not a sterte .
To ben diffamed . falsly . / yf that he .
Hathe trespaced . vnto my brothren . and to me .
For though I telle . not his ꝓpropre name
Men shalle wele knowen . / it is the same
By symonye . / and be other circumstaunces
Thus quite folke we folke . / þᵗat doon vs displesaunces .
Thus spitte I out my venym . vnder hewe
Of holynesse . to seme holy and trewe
But shortly myn entent I wille devyse .
Radix omnium . malorum est cupiditas .
Thus gan I preche . / ayens the same wise
Soche that I vse . / and that is Avarice
But they I my self . be gilty in that synne
Yit can I make other folke to wynne .
Fro Avarice . and sore to repent
But that nys nought . / my pⁱrincipall entent
I preche nothyng . / but for covetise
Of this mater I it ought I nowe suffise
Then telle I of ensamples . / many oōn
Of olde stories . / longe tyme agoōn
For lewde peple . / loven tales olde
Whiche thynges . can they wele report ⁊and holde
What trowe ye . whiles that ye may preche
And wynne golde . and siluer . for I teche
That I wole have in pouert wilfully
Nay . nay I thought it neuer truly
For I wille preche . / and begge . / in sondry londes
I wille nought do . no laboure . / wᵗith my hondes
And make baskettis . / and lye therbye .
Be cause I wille . not begge ydelly
I wille noōn . of the Apostles . / counterfete
I wille haue . mony . / chese . and . whete

l.hi: Alle were it youen of the porest page

div.l: Alle were it youen . / of the porest page
Othre of the porest / . widewe . / in oo . vilage
Alle though hir children . / shulde sterue . / or famyne
Nay I nil . drinke . / no . licoure of the vyne
And haue a ioly wenche . / in euery toun .
But herkeneth lordynges . / in conclusiou
Your lokyng is . / that I shalle telle . A . tale
Nowe haue I dronke . A . draught of corny Ale
Be god I hope . I shalle telle you A thing
That shalbe resoun . / at youre likyng
For though my self . / be right a vicious man
A more ille tale yit telle you I can .
Whiche I am wonte to preche . for to wynne
Now . holde youre pees . my tale I will begynne .

Here endith the prolog of the Pardoner
And here begynneth . his tale folowyng
IN Flawnders . whilom . was on . A . companye .
Of yong folke . / that haunteden folie
As . Riot . hasard . / stewes . and Tavernes
They daunce and pleye . at Dys bothe day ⁊and night
And eten also . and drunken . / ouer aller here might
Thorugh whiche they done . / the Deuel sacrifice
Wᵗithynne the Deuels temple . / in cursed wise
The superfluites . / abhominable .
Here othes ben so . gret . / and dampnable .
That it is to grislye . / for to here hem swere
Oure blissid lordes . / body . / theye to . tere
Hem thought Iewes rent hym not ofte I nowe . //
And ilke of hem . / at othre synnes lowe .
And right anoōn . / cam tumblisters
Fetys . and smalle . / and yong fruisteres
Syngers . wᵗith harpes . / bawdes . wafereres .
Soche ben . verry . / the develles . officers
To kyndell . and blowe . / the fyre of letcherye .
That is annexed . / to glotenye .
Luxuria est in vino et in ebrietate
The holy writte take I to witnesse
That letcherie is in wyn . and dronkenesse .
Loo . how . that dronken . / lothe vnkendely
Laye . be his doughtren two . vnwetynglye .
So drunke he was . / he nist what he wrought
And therfore . sore repente . hym ouȝte .
Heroudes . / whoso wille . / the stories seche .
There may ye lerne . / and by ensample teche
Whan he of wyn . was replete . at his feste .
Right . at his owne table . / yaf his heste
To sleen the baptist Iohn . full giltles
Senek saithe eke . / good wordes douȝtles .
He saithe he can . / no . difference fynde .
Betwix . A . man . that is . oute of his mynde
And A man . / that is drunkelew
But that woodnesse . is . fallen in . A . shrew .
Perseuereth . lenger . / than dothe dronkenesse .
O . glotenye . / full of cursidnesse .
O . cause . first . / of oure confusioıı̄un .
O . originall . / of oure Dampnaciou
Tille criste had bought oute . wᵗith his blood ageyn
Lo how . dere . and shortly . was to sayn
Abowte was . the cursed vilanye
Corrupte was . alle this worlde . through glotenye .
Adam . oure fader . / and his wif alsoo .
From . paradys . / to laboure . and to . woo .
Were dryuen . for that vice . / it is no dred .
For whiles that Adam . / fasted as I rede
He was in paradys . / and whan that he
Ete of the frute . defended on a tre .
Anoon he was out caste . to woo and payne .
O . glotenye . on the whele wele ought vs playne
O . wiste a . man . / how many maladies
Foloweth of excesse . / and of glotenyes
He shulde be the more . mesurable .
Of his diete . sittyng at the table .
Allas . the shorte throte . / the tendir mouthe
Maketh . that Erst . / and west . Northe ⁊and Southe
In erthe . in eyre . in water . men to swynke
To geten a gloton . / mete and drinke
Of this mater . oo . Powle wele canst þᵘ trete .
Mete . vnto wombe and wombe eke to mete
Shalle god distryven . / bothe as Powle seithe .
Allas a fowle thyng . / is be my feithe
To saye this worde . / and fowler is the dede .
Whan men drinke . / of the white . and of the Rede .
That of his throte . / he makithe his pryue
Through ilke cursed . superfluite
The Apostill wepyng . / seithe full pitouslye
There walken many . of soche . you tolde haue I
I seye it nowe wepyng . / with pitous voice
There ben enmyes . on cristes crois
Of whiche the ende . is dethe . / the wombe is here god .
O . wombe . O holy . O . stynkyng Codde .
Fulfilled . of Dunge and of corrupcioıı̄un //
At either ende . / of the fowle is the sowne
Howe gret coste . / and laboure is to fynde
Thes Cokes . how . theye stampe . streyne . ⁊and grynde
To turne substaunce . in to Accident
To fulfille . / alle thy likerous talent
Oute of the hard . bones . stampe thaye
The marye . for they cast not aweye
That may go thorugh the golet . / softe ⁊and soote
Of spicery . / of leves . / barke and roote .
Shalben . his sawce I made be delyte
To make hym yit . / a newe appetite
But certes he that haunteth . soche delites
Is dede whiles . that he leueth . in the vices
A leccherous thyng is wyn and dronkenesse
Is full of stryvyng . / and of wretchidnesse
O . Drunken man . disfigured . / is thy face
Fowle is thy brethe . / fowle art þᵘ to enbrace
And thorugh thy dronken nose . / semeth thy sowne
And as þᵘ saidyst . aye . sampson . sampsoıı̄un .
And yit god woot . sampsoıı̄un . dranke nevyr no wyn .
Þᵘ fallest euer . / as it were a stiked swyne
Thy tonge is loste . / and alle thy honest cures
For drunkenes . / is verry sepultures
Of mannys witte . / and of his discrecioıı̄un
In whom that drinke . / hathe dominacioıı̄un
He can noo counseile kepe . / it is no . drede .
Nowe kepe you . from the white . / ⁊and from the Redde .
Namlye from . the white wyne . of lepe
That is to selle . / in Fysshe strete . / or in chepe
This wyne of spayne . / crepithe subtillye
In othre wnes wynes growyng faste bye .
Of whiche there risethe . / soche fumosite
That whan A man . / hathe drunken drauȝtes thre .
And weneth . that he be at home . in . Chepe
He is in spayne . / right at the toıı̄unn of lepe
Nought at the Rochell . / ne at Burdeux toun
And thanne wolen theye saye . sampson . sampsoıı̄un .
But herkeneth lordynges I you praye
That alle the souerayne . actis . / dare I saye
Of victories . / in the olde testament
That thorugh verry god . / that is omnipotent
Were doon in abstinens . / and in praiere
Lokethe the bible . / and there ye may it lere
Lokithe Attilla . the gret conqueroᵘur
Died in his slepe . / wᵗith shame and dishonoure
Bleding aye at his Nose . / in dronkenesse
A Capteyne . shuld lyve . / in sobirnesse
And ouer alle this . / aviseth you right wele .
What was cōmmaunded . / vnto samuel
Nought . samuel . / but lamuel . / seye I
Redithe the bible . and fyndithe expreslye
Of wyne yeuyng . to hem . that han . Iustice
Nomore of this . / for it may wele suffice
ANd nowe that I haue spoken . of glotenye .
Now . wille I speke . ⁊and Defende you of hasardye
Hasard is verry . moder . / of lesynges
And of Disseyte . / and cursed forswerynges
Blaspheme . of criste . / and man sleynges alsoo .
Of bataile of tyme . / and other moo .
It is repreef . and contrarye to honoure //
For to be holde . / A . comoıı̄un . hasardour
And euer the higher . / he is of estat
The more I holden . / is desolat
If that A . prince . / vse hasardie
In alle gouernaunce . / and polecye .
He is . as by comoun . opynioun .
I holde the lasse . / in reputacioıı̄un
From . Caleydoyne . / to make hym alliaunce
And . whan he came . / it happed this chaunce
That alle the grettest . / that were of this lande .
Playing at the hasard . / he hem fande
For whiche assone . / as that myght be .
He stale hym home . / ayen . to his cuntre .
And seide there I wille not lese my name .
I ne wille not take . / of me so gret diffame
You for to allye . / to noon . hasardours /
Sendithe othre wyse . embassatours
For be my trouthe . / me were leuer to deye .
Then I to you . A sardours . / shulde alleye .
For ye that ben so glorious . / in honours
Shall not alleye . / to you hasardours
As be my wille . / ne as be my trete
This wise philosrphre . / thus said to me
Loke þᵘ vse no pleye . / of dys . in thy hous
Loke eke that the kyng . / Demetrius .
Sent hym A . peire of dyes . / of gold in scorn
For he had vsed . / hasardye . / there beforne
For whiche he hilde . / his glorie and renoun
At no . value . / of reputacioıı̄un
Lordys myght fynde . / other maner pleye .
Honest I nough . / to dryve . the day aweye
Now wille I speke . / of Othes . / false and grete
A worde . or . two . / as othre bokes entrete
Gret swering is A . thyng . abhominable .
And false sweryng is more reprouable
The hie god . forbad . / sweryng at alle
Witnesse of Mathew . / but in specialle
Of sweryng . seithe the holy Ieremie
Þᵘ shalt swere sothe . / thyn othes . / and not lye
And swere in Dome . / and eke in rightwisnesse
But idell swering . / is a cursidnesse .
Be holde and see . / that in the firste table .
Of high goddes . hestes honourable .
How that the secounde heste of hym is this
Take nought my name in ydilnesse . amys
Loo . rather . he forbedith . / soche sweryng
Or . homicide . or any other . / cursed thyng .
I saye as by ordre . / thus it standithe
This knowethe that his hestes . vnderstondethe .
How . that the secounde heste of god is that
And furthermore I wille the telle alle plat
That vengeaunce . / shalle not parte / from his house
That of his othes . / is so . outerageous
Be god . his precious herte . and his nayles
And by his blood . / that is in hailes
Seven is my chaunce . / and thyne is fyve and thre .
Be goddes armes . yf þᵘ false pleye me
This Daggar shalle thorugh thyn herte goo .
This frute comethe of the bicched bones twoo
Forsweryng . Ire falsnesse . homicide //
Now . for the love of criste . / that for vs deide
Leuethe . your othes . / bothe gret and smale .
For cristes sake . / and herkne to my tale .
These Riotours . three . / of whiche I telle .
Long or pryme . / rang any belle
Were sette hem . in A . Taverne . / to drinke
And as theye sat . / theye harde A . belle clynke .
By forne a . corps was caried . / to his grave .
That oon of hem . / gan calle to his knave
Goo . bet qd he . / and aske redilye
What corps is this . / that passith fast bye .
And loke that þᵘ reporte . his name wele
Sir qd this boye . / it nedethe neuer a . dele .
It was me tolde . / or ye came here . twoo . oures
He was parde . / an olde felawe of youres
Alle sodeynly . / was he slayne to night
For drunke . as he sat on his benche vp right
There came A . pryve theef . / men clepe dethe .
That in his contre . / alle the peple slethe
And wᵗith his spere . / he smote his herte a twoo
And went his weye . / wᵗithouten woordes moo
And maister . or ye come . / in his presence
He hathe A . thousande slayne . / this pestilence
Me thynketh it were necessarye .
For to be ware . / of soche an aduersarie
Bethe . redy . / for to mete hym euer more .
Thus taught me my Dame I seye nomore .
Be seynt . Marie . / seid the Tavernere
The childe seithe sothe . / for he thath slayne to yere
Hense . ouer A myle . wᵗithynne . A . gret vilage
Bothe man . and . womman . / Childe and . Page .
I trow . his habitacioıı̄un . / be there .
To ben . Avised . / gret wisdom it were .
Er that he did . / A . man dishonoᵘur
Ya goddys Armys . / qd this Riotoᵘur
Is it soche perelle with hym for to mete .
I shalle hym seke . / be weye . / and eke be strete .
I make avow . / goddys digne bones .
Herkne felawes . / we thre . ben alle ones
Lete eche of vs . holde vp his hand . / to othre .
And eche of vs . / by come others brothre .
And we wille slee this false traitoure dethe .
He shalbe slayne . / he that so many slethe .
Be goddys dignite . / or it be night
Togidre haue these thre . / hir hertes knytt .
To lyve and deie . / ilke of hem to othre .
As thouȝ he were . / his owne . sworne brother
And vp they stirte . / alle dronke . in this . rage
And forthe theye goon . / toward that vilage
Of whiche the Taverner . / hathe spoken of beforn .
And many A grisly othe / then have they sworne .
And cristes blissed body . / theye to rent
Dethe shalbe Dede . / yf we may hym hent
Whan they gan goon . / not fully A . myle .
Right as theye wolde . / have treden . ouer a stile
An olde and A pore mān . / / wᵗith hem he mette .
Thus mekely . the olde man . hem grette .
And seid thus . / nowe lordes god you see
The prowdest of these . Riotours thre .
Answerid . ageyn what carle wᵗith harde grace ///
Why art þᵘ alle for wrappyd . / saf thy face
Why . leuyst þᵘ soo . long / in soo . gret age .
This olde man . / gan loke in his visage
And said thus . / for I can not fynde .
A man thouh . that I walked vnto ynde
Neither . in Cite . / ne in village
That wille chaunge . / his youthe . for myn age .
And therfor mot I haue . / my age stille
As longe tyme . / as it is goddis wille
Ne dethe allas nill . nought . haue my lif
Thus walke I like A . retcheles caityf
And on the ground whiche that is my modres gate
I knokke with my staf . / erlye . and late .
And seye leve moder . / lete me Inne
Lo . how I wanse . / flessh . / blood . and skynne
Allas . whan shalle . my bones . ben at reste
Moder with you . wille I chaunge my cheste .
That in my Chambre . / longe tyme have be .
Ya . for an here clowte . / to wrappe me
But yit to me . she wille not doo . that grace
For whiche full pale . / and welked is my face
But sirs . to you . / it is noo . curtesye
To speken . to . an olde man . / vilanye .
But he trespace . in woorde . / or elles in dede
In holy writ . / ye maye your self wel rede
Ne dothe nat to an olde man . / hoor . vpon his hede
Ye shulue arise . / wherfor I yeue you rede
Ne doo nat to an olde man . / noon harme nowe
Nomore than men . / dede vnto you .
In age yf that ye so long tyme abide
And god be wᵗith you . whethre ye goo or Ride . /
I mote go . thider . where as I haue to goo .
Naye olde Cherle . / be god thou shalt not soo .
Saide . this othre . / hasardoure . anoōn
Þᵘ partest not soo . lightly . / be seint Iohn
Thou spake right nowe . / of thilke traytoᵘur dethe
That in this Cuntre . / alle oure freendys sleethe
Have here my trouthe . / as þᵘ art his aspie
Telle me where he is . / or þᵘ shalt . abye .
Be god . and be the holy sacrament .
For sothly þᵘ art oon . / of his assent .
To sleen . vs yong folke . / thou false thef .
Now sirs . that it be to you . soo leef
To fynde dethe . / torne vp . this croked weye .
For in that . Grove . / I lafte hym be my feye
Vndir a tre . and there he wille abide
Ne for your boost . he wille hym . nothyng hide
Se ye that Oke . / right there shalle ye hym fynde .
God save you . / that bought you . ayen mankynde
And you amende . / thus seide . this olde man
And euery of these Riotours . / ran .
Tille they came . to the . Tree . / and there they fonde
Of Floroynes fyne of gold I cornen rounde .
Wele nigh a vij . busshelles as them thought
No lenger than after Dethe . / theye sout sought
But eche of hem . / so . glad was of the sight
For that the floreyns . / so faire ben . and bright
That down theye sett hem . / by the precious hoord .
The werste of hem . / he spake the furst woord .
Brethren qd . he . / take kepe . what I seye
My witte is gret . / theye that I boorde and pleye .
This tresoure hathe fortune . / to vs yeuen . //
In myrthe . and iolite . / oure lyfe to lyven .
And lightly . / as it comethe . / so wille we spende
Eye . goddys / precious . dignite . who . wende
To daye . that we shuld haue . / so fayre a grace
But might this golde . / be caried from this place
Home to myn house . / or elles vnto youres
Than . myght we seie . / it were alle oures
Thenne . were . we . / in high felicite
But truly . be daye . / it may not bee
Menne . wolde seie . / that we were theues strong .
And for oure owne . / tresoure . / do . vs honge
This tresoure . must I caried be by night
As wisly . and as slylye . as it myght
Wherfor I rede . / lete loke . among vs alle
Be drawe . / and lete see . / where the Cut wille falle
He that hathe . the Cutte . / withe herte blithe
Shalle rynne . to Towne . / and that full swithe
To bryng vs breed . and wyn . / full priuelye
And twoo of vs . / shalle kepe full subtillye
This tresoure wele . / and yf he wille not taryen
Whan that it is night . we wille the tresoure carien
By oon assent . where as vs lust best
That oon of hem . / brought In his feste
And bad hem drawe . / and loke on whom it wolde falle .
And it fille . on the yongest . / of hem alle
And forthe towarde . / the Towne . he wente a noōn
And also sone . / as he was goōn
That oon of hem spake thus . vnto that othre .
Þᵘ wost wele . / þᵘ art my owne sworne brothre .
Thy prophite wille I wille telle the . / anoon .
Þᵘ woste wele . / that oure felawe is goon And here is golde .
And here is golde . / and that full gret plente
That it shall be departed . / among vs thre
But natheles . / yf I can shape it soo .
That it departed were . / amonges vs twoo .
Had I nought done . / A . freendes turne to the
That other answere I not howe that might be
I woot weell that the golde is oure twoo
What sholde we seie . / what sholde we doo .
Shall it be counseill seide the first shrewe
And I shall tellen in woordys fewe
What shulde we doon . / ⁊and bring it wele abowte
I graunte qd . that othir . oute of dowte
That be my trouthe I wille not the be wreye .
Nowe qd the first . / þᵘ woste wele . we ben tweye .
And tweyn of vs . shall strenger been . / than oon
Loke whan that he is sette . and than a noon
Arise as thowe þᵘ woldest . / with hym pleye
And I shall rynne hym thorugh . / the sides tweie
Whilest that þᵘ strugelest wᵗith hym in game
And wᵗith thy Dagger . / loke þᵘ do the same
And than shall all this golde . departed be
My dere freende . bitwix the . and me
Then maye we bothe . / oure lustis fulfille
And pleie at the Dyes . / right at your owne wille
And thus accorded . ben those shrewes tweie
To sleen the thirde . / as ye herde me seye .
This yongest whiche that went vnto the town
Full ofte in herte . / he rolleth vp and down
The beaute of theise Floreyns . newe ⁊and bright
O . lord . qd he . / yf soo . were that I myght
All this tresour wynne to my self allone . ///
There nys noman . / that lyuethe vnder the trone
Of god that sholde lyve as mery as I
At the last the Fende . / oure enmy
Put in his thought . / that he shulde poisoıı̄un beye
Wᵗith the which he might sleen his felawes tweye .
For why . the Fende fan hym in soche lyvyng
That had leve hym to sorowe bryng
For this was vttirlye . / his entent
To sleen hem bothe . / and nevir to repent .
And forthe he gothe . / no lenger nolde he tarye
In to the town . / vnto A . potycarie
And preyed hym . / that he wolde selle
Sōme poisoıı̄un . / that he might . his Rattes . quelle .
And eke there was A . Polcat / . in his hawe
That as he seide . / his Capons had I slawe .
And seide he wolde wrekyn hym be night yf he might
Of vermyn . that distroied hym by night
The Potecary answered . / þᵘ shalt haue
A . thing that alle so . god my sowle save
In alle this world . / there nys no creature .
That eten and drunken . hath of this confecture
Nought but the mountenᵃunce . / of A . corn of whete .
That he ne shalle . his lif anoon for lete .
Ya sterve he shalle . / and that in lasse while
Then þᵘ wilt gon a . pace . not but a myle .
This poisoıı̄un is so strong . / and so violent
This cursed mān . / hathe in his hond I hent
This poisou in A . boxe . / and sithen he ran
In to the next strete . / vnto A . mān
And borowed hym . / large botelles three .
And in the tweyne . this poisoıı̄un poured he
The thyrde he keped clene . for his drinke /
The thridde he kepid clene for his drinke
For alle the night . he shope hym . for to swynke
In carying of that gold . out of that place
Whan this Riotour . / wᵗith sory grace
Had filled wᵗith hym . / his gret botelles three
And in the tweine . / this poisoıı̄un poured he
What nedith it to sermone . / therof more
For right as theye had cast his dethe afore
Right so theye have hym slayne . / and that anoōn
And whan this was doōn . / than spake that oon
Nowe late vs drinke . / and sitte and make vs merye
And afterward we wolne his body berye .
And aftirward it happed . them per cas
To take the Botell . / there the poisoıı̄un was
And dranke . / and yaf his felaw drinke alsoo .
For which . anoōn . they steruen . / bothe twoo
But certes I suppose . / that Auycenne
Wroot neuer in no canoıı̄un . / ne in no fenne .
Mo . wonder sorowes . / of empoisonnyng
Thus had ther wretchis . / here endyng
Thus endid ben thes homicides twoo
And eke the false empoisener also .
O . cursid synne . / full of cursidnesse
O . traytours . homiciders . / O . wikkidnesse
O gloteny . O luxurie . O . hard hasardie
Thou Blasphemer . / of criste with vilanye
And othes grete of vsage . / and of pride
Allas . mankynde . / how maye it be tide
Therto thye creature . / whiche that the wrought
And with the precious blood . / that he bought
Thou art so fals . and soo . vnkynde allas
Nowe good men . / god for yeve you your trespas //
And ware you from the synne . / of Auarice
Myn holy pardoıı̄un . / may you alle warisshe .
So that ye offre nobles . or sterlinges .
Other . elles siluer . spones . brochys . Rynges .
Boweth your hede . vnder this holy bulles
Cometh vp ye wifes . / offrethe your wolles .
Your name I entre here . / in my Rolle anoōn
In to the blisse of heven . / shull ye goōn
I you assoile . / be my hih power
Ye that wille offren . / as clene . and eke as cleer
As ye were born . / and sirs . / loo . this I preche
And Ihıı̄un criste . / that is oure sowles leche
So graunt you his pardoıı̄un . / to receyue
For that is beste I wille not you deceyue .
But sirs . oo . word for gat I in my tale .
I haue relikes and ꝑpardoıı̄un in my male
As faire as any man in England
Whiche were me I youe by the popes hond
Yf any of you wille . / of deuocioıı̄un
Offren . and have . myn Absolucioıı̄un
Comethe forthe anoōn . / and knelith down here .
And ye schulne . haue my ꝑpardoıı̄un . that is so dere .
Or elles takithe . pardoıı̄un . / as ye wende
Alle newe and fresshe . / at euery townes ende
So that ye offren alweye newe . and newe
Nobles . and pens . whiche that ben good and trewe
It is an honour to euery . that is here .
And ye may haue A . sufficiant pardonere .
To Assoile you in the cuntre . as ye ride
For aduentures . whiche that may be tide .
For parauenture there may falle oon or twoo
For parauenture . there may falle . oon . or twoo
Down of his hors . / and breke his nekke . a . twoo .
Loke which a . suerte . / it is to you alle
That I am . in your felaship I falle .
That may assoile you . bothe more and lasse .
Whan that the sowle . / shall fro the body passe .
I rede that oure Oost / . / shalbe gynne
For he is moste in volupte of synne
Come forthe sir Oost / . / and offre furst anoōn
And . þᵘ shalt kisse . / the Relikes euerichon
Ye . for A . grote . vnbokille . anoōn thy purs
Nay qd he . thanne . haue I cristes curs
Lat be qd he . it shalle not be so theche .
Þᵘ woldest make me . to kisse . / thyn olde breche
And swere it were . / A . Relike . of A . seynt
Thouȝ it were . with thy foundement depeynt
But be the crosse . whiche seynt Eleyne fonde
I wolde I had . thy colyons / . in my honde
In stete of Relikes . / or of sentuarie
Lete cut hem I wille helpe the hem carie
They shulne be shryned . / in an hogges torde .
This Pardoner ne answered not / a . woorde .
So wrothe he was . he wolde no woord saye .
Nowe qd oure Oost . / I wille no lenger playe .
With the ne wᵗith noōn other . angry man
But right anoōn . / the worthy knight began
Whan that he sauȝ . / that alle the peple . louȝ
Nomore of this . / for it is right I nouȝ
Sir pardoner be mery and glad of chere .
And ye sir Oost . that ben to me so dere .
I pray you that ye kisse . the pardoner . /
And Pardoner I pray the . / that þᵘ drawe the ner .
And as we dede . / lete vs laughe . and pleie
And wᵗith that worde . / they riden forthe here weye
Here endith the . Pardoners tale

div.l: (base) That euere in oon was drawyng to that place
(base) This yonge Monk that was so fair of face
(base) Aqueynted was so with the goode man
(base) Sith that hir firste knewliche bigan
(base) That in his hous as famulier was he
(base) As it is possible any freend to be
(base) And for as muchel as this goode man
(base) And eek this Monk of which that I bigan

(base) And he agayn he seith nat ones nay

(base) And ech of hem gan oother for tassure

(base) Free was daun Iohn and manly of dispence

(base) To doon plesance and also greet costage

(base) For which they were as glad of his comyng

div.l: (base) This noble Monk of which I yow deuyse
(base) Hath of his Abbot as hym list licence
(base) By cause he was a man of heigh prudence
(base) And eek an Officer out for to ryde
(base) To seen hir granges and hir bernes wyde
(base) And vnto Seint Denys he comth anon
(base) Who was so welcome as my lord Daun Iohn
