div.l: Whan endid was the tale of Melibe
And of Prudence and of her
Oure Oost said as I am feithfull man
And by the precious corpus Madruan
I had leuer than a barell of good Ale
That good leef my wiff had herd this tale
For she nys nothyng of soche pacience
As was this Melibeus wif Prudence
By goddys bones whan I bete my knaves
She bryngeth me my gret clubbed staves
And crieth slee the doggꝭes euerichoıı̄un
And biddith me breke he bak ⁊and bon
And yf that any neiȝbour of myn
Will not to my wif in chirche inclyne
Or be so hardy to here trespace
When she cometh home she rampeth in my face
And crieth false coward wreke thi wif
By corpus bonys I wille haue thi knyf
And lt haue my distaf and go spynne
Fro day to night right thus she wil begynne
Allas she saithe that euer I was shape
To wedde a mylksoppe or a coward Ape
That wilbe ouerleide wᵗith euery wight
st not stonde wᵗith thy wif a right
This is my lif but that if I wolde fight
And oute atte dore anoon I moot be diȝt
Or elles I am loste but yf that I
Be lik a wilde lyon fool hardy
I wot wele she wille do me slee som daye
Som neiȝbour and than go my waye
For I am pareilous wᵗith a knif in honde
Albe it that I dare not with hir stonde
For she is bigge in Armes be my feithe
That shall he fynde that here mysdothe or seithe
But lete vs passe aweye from this matere
My lord sir Monke he seithe be mery of chere
For ye shulle telle a tale trulye
Loo Rouchestre stant here fast bye
Ride forthe myn owne lord breke not oure game
But be my trouthe I knowe not thyn name
Wheder I shulle calle you my lorde Daun Iohn
Or Daun Thomas / or Daun Albon
Or of what house be ye be your fader kynne
I vowe to god thou hast a full fayre skynne
It is a gentle pasture there þᵘ gost
Vpon my feith þᵘ art not like no penᵃnt ot a goost
Ne semys thou art sedime Officere
Som worthy sexten or semme Celere
For be my fader soule as to my dome
Þᵘ art a maister whan þᵘ art at home
No pore cloisterer ne no pore Nouice
But a gouernoᵘur wysly and wyse
And therwᵗithalle of brawnes ⁊and of bones
A wele faring persone for the nones
I pray to god yeue hym confusion
That furst the brought vnto Religioıı̄un
Þᵘ woldest abene a tredfule a right
Haddest þᵘ as gret leve as þᵘ hast myght
To parfourme alle thy luste in engendrure
Þᵘ haddest be geten many a creature
Allas thy werest þᵘ so wide a Cope
God yeve me sorowe and I were a Pope
Not only þᵘ but euery mighty man
Thouh he were shore hie vpon his pan
Sulde haue a wif for alle this world is lorne
Religioıı̄un hathe take vp alle the corne
Of tredyng ⁊and we borell men ben shrympes
Of feble trees there cometh wretchid ympes
This maketh that oure wyfes wille assaye
Of venus payment then mowe wee
God wot no lusshebornes pay ye
But be not wroth thouȝ that I pleye
Full ofte in game a sooth I haue hard seye
This worthy monk took alle pacience
And seide I wille do my diligence
As ferre as sowneth in to honeste
To telle you a tale or two or thre
And yf you luste herkene hiderwarde
I wille now sayne the lif of seynt Edwarde
Or elles tregedys first wille I telle
Of which I haue an hundred in my celle
Tregedy is for to tellen a certayn story
As olde bookys maken memorie
Of h stood in gret prosperite
And is I falle oute of high degre
Into myserye and endithe wretchidly
And theye ben versified comonly
Of six feet whiche that men clepe examytroıı̄un
In prose eke ben endited many on
And eke in metre in many a sondry wyse
Lo this aught you I now suffice
Nowe herkeneth yf you list for to here
But furste I you beseche in this matere
Although I be ordre telle not these thynges
Be it of Popes Emꝑperours or kynges
And aftir hir ages as mēn writen fynde
But telle hem some before and some behynde
And it cometh nowe to my rebembraunce
Haue me excused of my ignoraunce

l.hi: Here endith the Prolog of the Monkes tale

div.l: And here begynneth his tale folowyng
I will be waile / in maner of treiedrie
The harme of hem that stondith in high degre
And fellen soo that there nas no remedye
To bring hem outre of here aduersite
For certayne whan Fortune luste to flee
There may noman of hir the cours wᵗith holde
Beth ware by this ensamples / yong ⁊and olde
At lucifer / though he an Aungell were
And not a man at hym / I woll begynne
For they Fortune may noon aungell dere
From high degre / yit fille he for his synne
Doıı̄unn in to helle where as he yet is ynne
O lucifer . brightest of Aungelis alle
Now art þᵘ sathanas þᵗat maist not twynne
Out of miserye in which thou art falle
Loo Sampson which was annıı̄unciate
By the aungell long or his natiuitee
And was to god almyghty consecrate
And stood in noblesse whiles he might see
Was neuer soche another as was hee
To speke of strenght . and ther to hardynesse
But to his wifes . . tolde he his secre
Thorugh whiche / he slouh / him self for wrecchidnesse
Sampson this . noble . and myghty chᵃmpioıı̄un
Wᵗithouten wepen saf his handes tweye
He slowe and alle to rent the lyon
Towarde his weddyng . walkyng by the waye
His false wif so cowde hym please ⁊and preie
Tille she his counseile knewe ⁊and she vntrewe
Vnto his Foes his counseill . gan be wreye
And hym forsooke and toke an other newe
An hundred Foxes toke sampson for Ire
And alle here tailes he to gidre bande
And sett the Foxes tailes . alle on fyre
For he in euerye taile . had put a bronde
And they brent alle the cornes . in that londe
And alle here Olyues and here vynes eke
A thousand men eke he slowe wᵗith his honde
And had no wepen but an Asses cheke
Whan they wre slayne so thristid hym that he
Was well nygh lord lorn for which he gan to preye
god wold of his . peyne . haue some . pite
And send hym drynk . or elles must he deye
And of this Asses cheke . that was soo drye
Out of a wang toth . sprang anoon a welle
Of whiche he dranke I nowe . shortly to seie
Thus halpe hym god as Iudicum . can telle
By verry force . at Gasan . on a night
Maugre the philistiens . of that Citee
The gates of the town . he hath vp plight
And on his bak I caried hem qd he hath he
High on an hille . where as men maye see
O noble ⁊and myghty sampsou leef and dere
That strong and noble hath be
In alle this world ne had there ben thy pere
This sampsou never Sither Drank . ne wyne
Ne on his hede . came Rasour none ne shere /
By precepte of the massengre dyvyne
For alle his strenght was / in his here
And fully twenty yere by yere
He had of Israell . the gouernaunce
But aftir sone shalle he wepe many a tere
For wommen shull bringen hym to myschaunce
Vnto his lemman . Dalida he tolde
That in his . herys alle his strenght laye
And falsly to his fomen she hym solde
And slepyng vpon hir arme vpon a day
She made to clippe or shere his here a waye
And made his fomen alle his crafte aspien
And whan that they hym fond in soche arraye
Theye bande hym fast . and put out his eyen
But or his here were I . clipped or I shave
There was no band / that might hym bynde
But now is he in prisou put in a Cave
Where as they made hym at the querne grynde
O noble sampsou strengest of mankynde .
O whilom / Iuge in glory and in Richesse .
N thow seye wᵗith thyn eyen blinde
Sethin from wele
The ende of theise iefs was I shall seye
His fomen made a feest vpon a daye
And made hym as here fool beforn hym playe
And this was at the temple of gret arraye
But at the laste he made a fowle a fray
For he two postes shoke and made hem falle
And down felle temple . and alle there it laye
And slow hym self . and eke his fomen alle
This is to sayne the Prynces euerichoon
And ek a thousand bodies were there slayne
With fallyng of the gret temple of stoon
Of sampsou ne will I nomore sayne
Beth ware of this ensample olde ⁊and playne
That noman telle his counseill tille hir wyfes
Of suche thyng as they wolde haue . secre fayn
Yf that it touche hir lymes . or here lyfes
Of Ercule the souerayn conqueroᵘur
Seyng his werkes leude and high renon
For in his tyme of strenth bare the floᵘur
He slowe ⁊and rafte the skynne . from the lyoıı̄un
He of seynt tawres . leide the boste a doun
He Arpyes . slowe . the cruell briddes felle
The golden Apples . he rafte fro the Dragou
He drow . oute . Serberoys . the hound of helle .
He slow the cruell tyrant Buserus
And made his hors . to frete hym flessh ⁊and bon
He slow . the verry serpent venymous
Of Achilles . two hornys brake he oon
And he slow . Cakus . in a Caue of stoon
He slowe the geaunt Antene the strong
He slowe the gresly boor . and that a noon
He bare the hede vpon his necke anoon
Was neuer wight the sethin the worlde began
That slowe so many monstres as did he
Thorughoute this wide world . his name ran
What for his strenght . and for his bounte
And euery Rem . went he for to see .
He was so strong . that noman might hym lette
At bothe worldes ende saithe trophe
In stede of bondys / he a piler sette
A lemman had this noble champioıı̄un
That hight Dyamyre . fressh as maye
And as clerkes make mencioıı̄un
She hath hym sent a shirte fressh ⁊and gaye
Allas this shirte . and welaweye
Envenymed was subtily with alle .
That he or that he had wered it half a daye
It made his bones from his flesshe falle
But neuertheles som clerke here excusen
Be oon that hight Nessus / that it maked
Be as be may . I wille here not accusen
But on his bakke the shirte . he werith alle naked
Tille that the flessh was for the venym blaked
And whan he sawe nōn other remedye .
In hote coles he hath hym self I raked
For wᵗith no venym deyned he to dye
Thus starf this worthy myghty Ercules .
Loo who may truste on Fortune any throwe
For hym that foloweth alle this world of prees
Or he be ware . full ofte . is I leide full lowe
Full wyse is he . that hym self can knowe
Bethe ware . for whan that Fortune lust to glose
Than waiteth she here man down to throwe
By soche a weye as . he wolde lest suppose
The mighty trone the precious tresoure
The glorious septre and the Rial mageste
That had the kyng Nabugadonosore
With tunge vnneth may discryued be
He twies wam Ierlm . the Citee
The vessell of the Temple he wᵗith hym ladde
At babyloyne was his souereyne see
In which his glorie and delite he hadde
The fairest children of the blood roiall
Of Ierlm he dede to gelde anoon
And maked eche of hem to ben his thrall
Among alle othre . Danyell was oon
That was the wisest childe of euerichoon
For he the dremes of the kyng expouned
Where as in Caldey clerke was there noon
That wiste to what fyne his dremes souned
This proude kyng lete make a stature of golde
Sixty cubytes long . and vij in brede
To . whiche ymage . bothe yong and olde
Commaunded he . to lowte ⁊and haue in drede
Or in . A . fourneys full of flammes rede
He shalbe brent / that wolde not obeye
But neuer wolde assent to that dede
Danyell ne his yong . felawes tweie
This kyng of kynges proude and elate
He wende god . that sitte in mageste
Ne might hym nought . be reue of his estat
But sodeynly he loste his dignite
And like a beste he semed forto be
And ete heye as an Oxe and lay ther oute
In reyne wᵗith wilde bestis all aboute walked he
Tille certayne tyme was come abowte
And like Egles fethers was his herys
His nailes like briddis clawes were
God releued hym certayne yeres
And yaf hym witte and than wᵗith many a tere
He thanked god and euer his lif in fere
Was he to done amys . or more trespace
And or that tyme I leid was on his bere
He knew well that god was full of might ⁊and grace
His sone which that hight Baltazar
That helde the Rewme after his faders daye
He be his fader coude nought be war
For prowde he was of herte . and of arraye
And eke an ydolatre . was he aye
His high estat . assured hym in pride
But Fortune cast hym down and there he laye
And sodeinly his Rewme gan deuide
A Feest he made vnto his lordys alle
Vpon a tyme he made hem blithe bee
And than his Officers . gan he calle .
Gōthe bryngeth forthe . my vessellis qd he
Which that my Fader in his prosꝑperite
Out of the temple of Iheri Ierlm be rafte
And to oure high goddys thanke wee
Of honoure . that oure eldres with vs lafte .
His wif his lordys and his concubynes
Ay drunken whils hir appetite laste
Out of theise noble vesselys / sondry wynes
And on a walle / this kynge his eyen caste
And sawe an hande armles / that wrot fulle faste
For fere of which he quoke . and sihed sore
This hande . that Baltazar . made so sore a gaste
Wrot . Mane . Techell . Phares and nomore
In alle that londe Magicien / was there noon
And seyde kg god to fader set
G and honoᵘur Reame tresour and Rent
And he was proude and noth hyn ne drede
And therfore god gret wreche on hym sent
And hym by afte the Rewme that he hadde
He was cast oute of mannys comp
Wᵗith Assys was his habitacion
And ete heye as a beest in wete ⁊and drie
Tille that he knew by grace ⁊and by reson
That god of heven hath dominacioıı̄un
Ouer euery Rewme and euery creature
And than had god of hy compassioıı̄un
And hym restored his Rewme ⁊and his figure
Eke thou that art his sone art proude alsoo
And knowest alle these thynges pryuely
And art Rebell to god and art his foo
Þᵘ dranke eke of the vessellis boldelye
Thy wif eke and thy wenches synfully
Dranke of the same vesselles sondry wynes
And heryed false goddys cursedlye
Therfor to the . shapen gret pyne is
This hande was sent from god that on the walle
Wrot Mane techel phares trust me
Thy Rewme is done . þᵘ weiest nought at alle
Dyvyded . is thy Rewme and it shalbe
To . Medes / and to ꝑperces yeuen qd he
And thilke same night the kyng was slawe
And Darius occupieth his degre
They he therto ne had neither right nor lawe
Lordynges here by example may ye take
How that in lordshipp is no siker nesse
whan fortune wylle a man forsake
b a wey his Rewme and his richesse
ek freendys bothe more and lesse
what man hath freendes thoruh fortune
Mys happe wille make hem enmyes I gesse
This prouerbe full sothe ⁊and full comune is
Cenobia of Palymere the quene
As writen ꝑpersiens of here noblesse
So worthy was in Armes ⁊and soo kene
That no wight passid here in hardynesse
Ne in lynage ne in other gentilnesse
Of the kinges blood of Perce is she discended
I saie that she nad nought moste fairenesse
But of hir shappe she might nought be amendid
From hir childehode I fynde that she fledde
Office of wommen and to wode she wente
And many a wilde hertes blood she shedde
Wᵗith arwes brode that she to hem sent
She was soo swifte that she anoon hem hent
And whan that she was elder she wolde kille
Lyoıı̄uns leopardes and beres alle to rent
And in here Armes wilde hem at here wille
She dorste wilde bestes dennes seke
And rynne in the mounteyne alle the night
And slepe vnder a busshe ⁊and she cowde eke
Wrastlen by verry force and by verry might
Wᵗith any yong man were he neuer so light
There might nothyng in here armes stonde
She kepte here maydenhede from euery wight
To noman deyned here to be bonde
But at the laste here frendys han here maried
To Odenak Prynce of that Cite
Alle were it soo that shem hem long taryed
And ye shuld vnderstonden how that he
Had soche fantasies as had she
But natheles whan they were knyt in feere
They lyueden in love and in felicite
For eche of hem loued other leef and dere
Saf oon that she nolde neuer assent
By no weye that he sholde be here lye
But ones for it was hir playne entent
To haue a childe the worlde to multiplie
And also sone as she might aspie
That she nas nought wᵗith childe with that dede
Thanne wolde she suffre hym to done his fantasye
Eftsone and nought but ones out of drede
And if she were wᵗith childe at thilke caste
No more shulde he pleie thilke game
Till fully fourty daies were past
Than wolde she ones suffre hym the same
Alle were this Odenak wilde or tame
He gate namore of hir for thus she saide
It was to wifes lechery and shame
In othir caas yf that man wᵗith hem pleide
Two sones by this Odenak had she
The which she kepte in vertu an in lecture
But now vnto oure tale turne wee
I saye that worshipfull creature
And wys therwith and large wᵗith mesure
So penible in the werre . ⁊and certeus eke
No more laboure might in werre endure
Was noon they all this world men sholde seke
Hir riche array myght nought be tolde
As well in vessell . as in clothyng
She was alle clad in perre and in golde
And eke she lafte not for noon huntyng
To haue of sondry tunges folk knowyng
Whan that she leyser hadde ⁊and for to entende
Whan she leyser had and for to entende
To leerne bokes was alle hir likyng
How she in vertu hir lif myght dispende
And shortly of this story for to entrete
So doughty was hir husbond as she
That they conquerid many Rewmes grete
In the orient wᵗith many a faire Citee
Appertenᵃnt vnto his mageste
Of Rome ⁊and wᵗith strong hond held hem faste
Nen neuer myght here fomen doon hem flee
Ay whiles that Odenak daies laste
Here batailes whoso lust hem for to rede
A gay sopor . the kyng . ⁊and other moo
And how that alle this processe fille in dede
Why she conqueryd ⁊and what title had therto
And after of here mischef ⁊and of here woo
How that she was beseged and I take
Leet hem vnto my mayster Petrak goo
That write I nowe of this I vndirtake
Whan Odenak was dede she mightily
The Rewmes helde and wᵗith hir ꝓpropir hande
Ageyn here Foes she faught truly
That there nas kyng ne prince in alle that lande
That he nas glad yf he that grace fande
That she ne wolde vpon his lond werreye
With here they made alliaunce be bande
To been in pees and let here ride and pleie
The Emꝑperour of Rome Claudyus
He hym beforne the Romayn Galyen
Ne durste nevyr be so coragyus
Ne noon Ermyne . ne noon Emꝑperoᵘur Egipcien
Ne surreyne . ne noon Araibyen
Wᵗithynne the Felde that durst wᵗith here fight
Leste that she wolde hem wᵗith here handes sleen
Or wᵗith hir meyne put hem to flight
In kynges habite went here sones twoo
As eyres of here Rewmes alle
And hermano / and Thimalio
Here names were . as ꝐPerciens hem calle
But ay fortune hath aye in here hony galle
This mighty queene may no while endure
Fortune oute of hir Rewme made hem falle
To wretchidnesse and to mys aduenture
Aurelyan whan that the gouernaunce
Of Rome came in to his handes tweie
He shope vpon this quene to do vengeaunce
And wᵗith his legyons he toke his weie
Toward Cenobye and shortly for to seye
He made here flee . and at the laste here hent
And fetred here . and eke hir children tweye
And wan the londe and home to Rome they went
Among these other thyng that he wan
Here chare that was . with golde wrought ⁊and perre
This gret Romayn this Aurelyan
Hath wᵗith hym lad for that men sholde see
Be forn this triumphe walketh she
Wᵗith gold chaynes on here nekke hangyng
Crowned she was as after here degre
And full of perry charged here clothyng
Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredfull to kunges and to Emꝑperours
Now gawreth the peple on here allas
And she that helmed was in starke stowres
And wan by force . tounes strong ⁊and toures
Shall nowe on here hede were a vytremyte
And she that bere the septer / full of flowres
Shall bere a dystaf here costes for to quyte
O noble o worthy petir glory of spayne
Whom Fortune helde so high in mageste
Wele ought men thy pitous dethe compleyne
Thy bastard Brothir made the to flee
And after at a sege be subtilite
Þᵘ were be trayed and lad to his tent
Where as he wᵗith his owne hand slowe the
Succedyng in the Rewme and in thy rent
The Felde of snowe . wᵗith an egle blak therynne
Caught wᵗith the lyme Rodde coloures as the glede
He brewe this cursidnesse . and alle the synne
The wicked nest was werker of this nede
Nought Charles Olyuer . that aye tooke good hede .
Of trouthe and honoure but of Armorekke
Genyloıı̄un Olyuer corupte for mede
Broughtest this worthy kyng in soche . a . brekke
Worthy Petir kyng of Cipre also .
That Alisaunder wan be high maistrye
Full many an hethen man . wroughtest þᵘ full woo .
Of whiche thyn owne legys had envye
And for nothyng . but for thy chiualrye
They in they thy bedde han slayne the be þᵉ morne
Thus gan fortune gouerne and gye
And out of ioye bring men in to sorowe
Of Melane gret Barnabo viscount
God of delite and scourge of lombardy
Why shulde not I thy fortune accounte
Sethyn in estat . thou climben were so hye
Thyn brothers sone . that was thy double allye
For he thy Nevew was . and sone in lawe
Wᵗithynne his prisou . made the to dye
Byt why ne hou woot I that þᵘ were slawe
Of the Erle hugelyn of Pyse the languor
There may no tunge telle for pite
But litle oute of Pyse stant a tour
In which toure in prisou put was he
And wᵗith hym ben his litle children thre
The eldest scarsly v . yere was of age
Allas fortune it was a gret cruelte
Soche birdys for to put in soche a cage
Dampned he was . to dye in that prisou
For Rogger which that bisshopp was of Pyse
Had on hym made a fals suggestiou
Thorugh whiche / the peple gan on hym arise
And putten hym to prisou in soche wise
As ye haue herde and mete ⁊and drynke he hadde
And therwithalle it was / full pore ⁊and badde
And oon a daye it felle . that in that oure
Whan that his mete was wont to be brought
The gayloure shett the dores of the toure
He herd it wele but he sawe it nought
And in his hert anoōn there fill a thought
That theye for hunger wolde doōn hem deyen
Allas qd he allas that I was wrought
Therwith the terys fille from his eyen
His sone yong that thre yere was of age
Vnto hym saide . fader why do ye wepe
Whan wille the gaylour . bryng oure potage
Is there no morsell breed / that ye do kepe
I am so hungry . that I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I might slepen euer
Then sholde noōn hunger in my body crepe
There is nothyng saf breed that me were leuer
Thus day be day this childe beganne to crye
Till in his Faders barme a down it laye
And seide farewele fader for I mot dye
And kissed his fader and dyed the same daye
And whan the wofull fader did hym saye
For woo his armes twoo he began to byte
And seid alas fortune and weleaweye
Thy false whele my woo alle may I wite
His children wende that it for hunger was
That he his Armes gnowe and not for woo
And said fader doo not soo allas
But rather ete the Flessh on vs twoo
Oure flessh yave vs take oure flessh vs froo .
And ete I nough . right thus to hym they saide
And after that wᵗithynne a day or twoo
They leide hem down . in his lappe ⁊and deied
Hym self dispeired . for hunger starf
Thus ended is the myghty Erle of Pyse
Fro high estat fortune from hym carf
Of this treiedrye . it ought I nouh suffise
Whoso wille here it . in a lenger wise
Redeth the gret Poete of ytaile
That hight Daunt . for he can it deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt not oo woord wille he faile
All thouȝh that Nero were as vicious
As any Fende . that lieth full lowe a down
Yit as he telleth swetheneus
This wide worlde had in subieccioıı̄un
Bothe Est and west and septemtryoıı̄un
Of Rubyes saphires and of perles white
Were alle here clothes brouded vp ⁊and down
For he in . gemmes gret gan delite
More delicat more pompous of arraye
More proude was neuer than he
That ilke cloth that he had werid a daye
After that tyme he nolde neuer it see
Nettes of golde threde . had he gret plente
To fisshe in Tybre whan hym luste to pleye
His lustes were as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frende wolde hym obeye
He Rome brent for his delicasie
The senatours he slow vpon a daye
To here how that men wolde wepe ⁊and crye
He slowe his brothir . and be his suster leye
His moder made he in pitous arraye
For he hir wombe slitte and to byholde
Where he conceyued was so welaweye
That he so litille of his moder tolde
No tere out of his eyȝen for that sight
Ne came but saide a faire womman was she
Gret wonder is that he couthe or myght
Be domesman of here dede beute
The boy wyn to bryng commaunded he
And dranke a noon . noon other woo he made .
Whan myght is ioyned vnto cruelte
Alas to depe wille the venym wade
In youthe a maister . had this Emꝑperour
To teche hym lecture and curtesye
For of moralite . he was the floure
And in his tyme but yf bookes lye
And whils . his mayster had of hym maistrie
He made hym so connyng and so sowple
That long tyme it was or tyrannye
Or any vice durste in hym vncouple
This Seneka of whiche I deuyse
By cause Nero had of hym soche drede
For he from vices wolde hym chastise
Discretly nought or word but as be dede
Sir wold he slayne . an Emꝑperour mot nede
Be vertuous and hate tyranntrie
For whiche he hym in a bathe made to blede
On bothe his armes . tille he must dye
This Nero had . eke of a custumaunce
In youthe ayen his maister . for to rise
Which afterward . hym thought a gret greuᵃnce
Therfor he made hym deye in this wise
But natheles . this senek the wise
Chees in a bathe to deye in this manere
Rather than han another tormentrye
And thus hath Nero slayne his maister dere
Now felle it soo that Fortune lust no lenger
The high pride of Nero to cherisshe
For though he was strong yit was she strenger
She thought thus be god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfilled of vice
In high degre an emꝑperoᵘur hym calle
Be god oute of his sete . I wille hym trise
Whan he leste weneth sonnest shalle he falle
The peple roos vpon hym on a night
For his defawte and whan he it aspied
Out of his dores anoōn he hath hym dight
Allone . ⁊and there he wende . han . ben allyed
He knokked faste ⁊and aye . the more he cryed
The faster shetten they . the dores alle
Tho wiste he wele . he had hym self begyled
And went his waye no lenger durst he calle .
The peple cried . and rombled vp and doun .
That wᵗith his eres herd he how they seide
Where is this false tyraunt this Neron
For fere almost oute of his witte abreide
And to his goddys pitously he seide
For socoure but it might not be tide
For dred of this hym thought that he died
And ranne in to a gardeyne hym to hyd
And in this gardeyne fande he cherles twey
That saten be a fere . full gret ⁊and rede
And to the cherles tweie he gan to preie
To sleen hym and to smyte of his hede
That to his body . whan that he were dede
Were no dispite I done for his diffame
Hym self he slow he cowde no bettir rede
Of which fortune lowh and had a game
Was neuer Capitayne vnder kyng
That Rewmes moo put in subieccioıı̄un
Ne strenger was in felde of alle thyng
As in his tyme nor gretter of renown
Ne more pompous in here presumpcioıı̄un
Thanne Olyuerne wᵗith fortune ay kest
So likerously and lad hym vp and down
Tille that he dede was . er that he wiste
Nought oonly that this world had of hym awe
For lesyng of Richesse and liberte
But he made euery man to reney his lawe
Nabugodhonasor was / lord seide he
Non other god . sholde honoured be
Ayens his heste no wight . dare trespace
Saf in Bethulya a strong citee
Where Eliachim . a prest was of that place
But take kepe . of the dethe of holiferne
A mydde his hoste he drunke laye alle night
Withynne his tent large as is a berne
And yit for alle his pompe ⁊and alle his might
Iudith a womman as he lay vpright
Slepyng his hede of smote . and fro his tent
Full priueli she stale from euery wight
What nedith it of kyng Antiochus
To telle his high and roiall mageste
His high pride . his werke venymous .
For soche another nas neuer noon as he .
Redeth which that he was in Machabe
And redeth the proude woordys that he saide
And why he fille from his high prosꝑperite
And in an halle how wretchidly he deyed
Fortune hym hadde enhaunced so in pride
That verryly he wende . that he might atteyne
Vnto the sterres vpon euery side
And in a Balaunce . to weie eche mountayne
And alle the Flodes of the see restreyne
And goddys peple had he moste in hate
Hem wolde he sle in torment and in pyne
Wenyng that god ne myght his pride abate
And for that Nichamor . ⁊and Thimothe
With Iewes were venquesshed myghtily
Vnto the Iewes soche an hate had he
That he had greythed his chare fulle hastilye
And swore and seide fulle dispitouslye
Vnto Ierlm he wolde eft sone
To wreke his Ire on it fulle cruelly thider whan he come .
God for his manace / hym so sore smot
With invisible wounde ay incurable
That in his guttes carf soo and bote
That his peynes were importable
And certeynly the wreche was resonable
For mani mannys guttes dide he payne
But fro his purpos cursed and dampnable
For alle his smert he nolde hym
But bad anoon apparaylen his Oost
And sodeynly or he was of it ware
God daunted alle his pride and alle his booste
For he so sore felle oute of his chare
That hurt his lymmes and his skynne to tare
So that he ne myght goo ne ride
But in a chayer men aboute hym bare
Alle for brosed bothe bak and side
The wreche of god so smoot hym cruellye
That in his body wicked wormes crepte
And therwith alle he stanke so horriblye
That noon of alle his meyne that hym kepte
Wheþe so he woke or elles slepte
Ne might nought the stynke of hym endure
In this myschef he wayled and he wepte
And knewe god aboue euery creature
To alle his / Oost and to hym alsoo
Full straunge was the stynke of this careyne
Noman hym might bere too ne froo
And in this stynke and in this horrible payne
He starf full wretchidly in a mountayne
This hath this robber and this homicide
That many a man made to wepe ⁊and pleyne
Soche guerdon as by longeth vnto pride
The story of Alisaunder is so comune
That euery wight that hath discreciou
Hath herd somwhat or alle of his fortune
This wide worlde . as in conclusiou
He wan be strenght or for his high renoun
They were glad for pees vnto hym sende
The pride of man and beste he leide adoun
Wherso he came vnto the worldes ende
Comparison yet neuer myght be maked
hym and another conqueroᵘur
For alle that world for dred of hym hath quaked
He was of knighthode and of fredom floure
Fortune hym made the higher of his honoure
Saf wyn and wommen nothyng might aswage
His high entent in Armes and laboure
So was he full of louvyng corage
What pite were it to hym then I you tolde
Of Daryus and an hundred thousand moo
Of prynces kynges Erlys bolde
Whiche he conquered ⁊and brought hem in too woo
I say as ferre as man may ride or goo
The world was his what sholde I more devyse
For thouȝ I write . or tolde you euer moo
Of his knighthode he might not suffice
Twelue yeer he reigned . as saithe Machabe
Philippes sone of Macedoyne he was
That furst was kyng of Grece the contre
O worthy gentill Alisaunder Allas
That euer sholde . falle soche a caas
Enpoysouned of thyn owne folke thou were
Thy Fortune hath torned in to an Aas
And yit for the ne wepe she neuer a tere
Whom shalle men yeue teres to compleyne
The dethe of gentilnesse and of fraunchise
That alle the worlde weldid in his demeyne
And yit hym thought . it myght not suffise
So fulle was his corage of high emprise
Allas who shalle me helpe to endite
False Fortune and poisen to dispise
The whiche twoo of alle this woo I wite
By wisdam manhede and by laboure
Fro humble hedde and fro roialle mageste
Vp roos he Iulius the conqueroᵘur
That alle the Occident by londe or see
By strenght of honde or elles be trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributarye
And sethyn of Rome than Emꝑperoᵘur was he
Tille that fortune wax his aduersarie
O myghty Cesar that in Tessalye
Ayens Pompeus fader thyn in lawe
That of the orient had alle the chyualrie
As fer that the daye begynneth dawe
Þᵘ therwith thy knighthode haste hem take ⁊and slawe
Saf fewe folke that wᵗith Pompeus fledde
Thorugh which þᵘ puttist all the orient in awe
Thanke fortune that so wele the spedde
But now a litle while I wol be wayle
This Pompeus this noble gouernoᵘur
Of Rome whiche that fleye at this batayle
I seye oon of his men a fals traitoᵘur
His heed of smoot to wynne hym favoᵘur
Of Iulius and hym the hed brought
Allas Pompeye of the orient conqueroᵘur
That fortune vnto soche affaunte brought
To Rome ayen repaireth Iulius
Wᵗith his triumphe laureat full high
But on a tyme . Brutus Cassius
That euer had of his high estat envye
Full pryuely had made conspiracye
Ayens this Iulius in subtile wise
And caste the place in whiche he sholde deye
Wᵗith Boydekyns as I shall you deuyse
This Iulius to the Capithole went
Vpon a daye as he was wonte to goon
And in the Capithole anoon hym hent
This fals Brutus on his fowle foon
And stiked hym wᵗith boydekyns anoon
Wᵗith many a wounde and thus they lete hem lye
But neuer gront he at no stroke but oon
Or elles as two but yf stories lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wele loued estatly honeste
That thouȝ his dedly woundes so sore smerte
His mantele ouer his hepes caste he
For noman shulde his priuite see
And as he laye of deying in a traunce
And wist verryly that ded was he
Of honeste yit had he remembraunce
Lucan to this story I recomende
And to swetou and vallerius also
That of this story writeth word and ende
How that these gret conqueroᵘurs twoo
Fortune was furste frende and sithen a foo
Noman ne truste vpon his favour longe
But haue here in awayte foreuer moo
Witnesse on alle these conqueroᵘurs strong
This Riche Cresus whilom kyng of luyde
Of whiche Cresus Ciquus sore hym drad
Yit was he caught a myddes alle his pride
And to be brent men to the fire hym ladde
But soche a Reyne doun fro the walken shadde
That slouȝ the fire and made hym to escape
But to be ware yet no grace he hadde
Tille fortune on the galews made hym gape
Whan he escaped was . he canne not stynte
For to begynne a newe reyne ayen
He wende wele for that fortune hym sent
Soche happe that he escaped thorugh the rayn
That of his hors he myght not be slayn
And soche a swefne vpon a night he mette
Of which he was so proude ⁊and eke so fayne
That in vengeaunce he alle his herte sette
Vpon a tre he was as hym thought
There Iubiter hym wisshe bothe halse ⁊and side
And Phebus eke a fayre towayle hym brought
To drye hym and therwith wax his pride
And to his doughter that stood hym beside
Whiche that he knewe be high sentence habounde
He bad her telle hym what it signified
And she his dremes beganne right thus expounde
The tree qd she the galewes is to mene
And Iubiter be tokeneth snow ⁊and Reyne
And Phebus wᵗith his towaile soo clene
Tho ben the sonne stremes for to sayne
Þᵘ xalt hanged be fader certayne
Reyne shalle the wasshe ⁊and sonne shalle the drye
Thus warned hym full plat ⁊and full playne
His doughter that was called Phanye
And hanged was Cresus the proude kyng
His roiall trone myght hym not availe
Tregedry is noon othir maner thyng
Ne can in synnyng crye ne be wayle
But that Fortune alweye wille assaile
Wᵗith vnware stroke the Rewmes that ben proude
For whan men trusteth here then wulle she faile
And oure couer hir bright face with a clowde
Here endithe the tale of the Monke

hi.hi: And here begynneth the Prolog of the Prest

div.l: HO qd the knight / good sir nomore of this
Than ye han seide / is right I nouh I wis
And mochell more / for litle heuynesse
Is right I nowe to mochell folke / as I gesse
Yoᵘur tales doon vs no disport / ne game
Wherfor sir monke / Daun Pers be yoᵘur name
I pray you hertily / telle vs somwhat elles
For sekyr nor for clyngyng of youre belles .
That on youre bridelle / hangeth on euery side
By heuen kyng / that for vs alle dyed
I shall for this falle doun for slepe
All thouȝ the snow / had never be so depe
Thanne had yoᵘur tale be tolde in vayne
For certanly as these clerkes sayne
Where as a man / may have non audience
Nought helpith to tellyn his sentence
And wele I woot / the substaunce is in me
If any thyng / shalle wele reported be
Sir say somwhat of huntyng / I you praye
Nay qd the Monke / I haue no luste to playe
Now lete another telle / as I haue tolde
Than spake oure Oost wᵗith rude speche ⁊and bolde
And seid vnto the Nonnes Preest anoōn
Come nere sir Preest come nere sir Iohn
Telle vs sure thynges / as may oure hertes glade
Be mery thou þᵘ ride vpon a Iade
What they thyn hors be fowle ⁊and lene
Yf he wille serve rekke the not a bene
Loke that thyn herte be mery euermoo
Yis Oost qd he soo mot I ride or goo
But I be mery I wys / I wilbe blamed
And right anoon / he hath his tale tamed
And thus he saide to vs euerichoon
This swete preste / this good man sir Iohn

l.hi: Here endith the Prolog of the Nonnes Preest
And here begynneth . his tale folowyng .

div.l: APore widewe somdele stope in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narwe cotage
Be sides a Groue stondyng in a Dale
This widew of which I telle you my tale
Sethin thilke daye that she was laste a wyf
In pacience / lad a fulle / symple lyf
For litle was / hir catelle / and hir rent
By husbondry soche as god hir sent /
She fande hir self and eke hir daughtren twoo
Thre large sowes had she ⁊and nomo
Three kene ⁊and eke a shepe that hight Malle
Full soty was hir boure // and eke here halle
In whiche she ete / many a slender mele
Of poynaunt sawce / she neded neuer a dele
No deynte morcell passid hir throte
Hir diete was accordaunt to here cote
Repleccioıı̄un ne made hir seke
A tempre diete . was alle hir Phisike
And excercise / and hert suffisaunce
The gowte letted hir nothynge to daunce
Ne poplexie ne shent nought here hede
No wyne ne drank she nother whight nor rede
Hir boord was serued moste / wᵗith whight ⁊and blakke
Milke and brown brede / in whiche she fonde / no lakke
Seynd bacoun ⁊and somtyme an eye or tweye
For she was as it had be / a manere of a deie
A gardeyne she had / enclosed all aboute
Wᵗ stikkes / and a drie diche wᵗith oute
In whiche she had / a cok / that hight Chaunteclere
In alle the land of crowyng was his pere
His voys was meryer / than the mery Orgoıı̄un
On masse daies / that in chirche goon
Wele siker was his crowyng in his logge
Than is a clokke in any Abbey or Orologge .
By nature he knewe eche assencioıı̄un
Of equynoxiall of thilke toun
For whan degrees xv were descended
That he knewe than it might not ben amended
His Combe was redder than the fyne coralle
And batailed as it were a castell walle
I like azure were his legges and his toon
His bille was blak and as geet it shone
His nayles whighter . than the lilye floure
And I like burnesshed gold was his coloure
This gentille cok . had in his gouernᵃnce
Vij . hennes for to don his plesaunce
Whiche weren his sustres and his ꝑparamoᵘurs
And wonder like to hym as of coloures
Of whiche the fairest hewed vnder throte
Was cleped faire Damysell Pertelote
Curteise she was discrete and debonaire
And compenable ⁊and bare hym self so faire
Sethens thilke daye . that she was seuenight olde
That truly she hathe the hert in holde
Of Chaunteclere loken in euery a lith
He loued here soo / that wele was hym therwith
But soche a ioye as it was . to here hem syng
Whan that the bright daye . began to spryng
In swete accord /. my leef is / faren in lande
For thilke tyme . as I haue vnderstonde
Bestis and birdys /. coude speke and syng
And so by felle / that in the dawenyng
As Chauntecler amonges / his wyfes alle
Sat on his perche . that was in the halle
And next hym sat his faire pertelote
This Chauntecler gan gronen in his throte
As a man is that in his dreme is dretched sore
And whan that Pertelotte thus herd hym rore
She was agaste . and seide herte / dere
What eyleth yow / to grone in this manere
Ye been a verey sleper fy / for shame
And he answered ⁊and seid . thus madame
I pray you . that ye take it to noo greef
By god me ment that I was in seche a meschef
Right nowe / that yit myn hert is sore a fright
Now qd he my sweuene rede a . right
And kepe my body . oute of fowle prisou
Me mette that I romed . vp . and doun
Wyth ynne oure yerd . where as I sawe a beste
Was i like an hounde ⁊and wolde haue made areste
Vpon my body and wolde haue had me dede
His coloure was betwixe white ⁊and rede
And tipped was his . tayle and bothe his eres
With blak onlike the remennt of his heres
His snowte smalle with glowyng eyen tweye
Yit of his loke for fere almoste I deye
This caused me my gronyng douteles
A voye . qd she fy on you hertles
Allas qd she . for by that god aboue
Now han ye lost myn herte / and my love
I can not love a coward . be my feithe
For certes what so any mān seithe
We alle . desiren . yf it myght be
To han husbondes . hardy wyse . ⁊and free
And secree ne no nygard ne noon fooll
Ne hym that is a cause of euery tooll
Ne noon avauntoure / be that god aboue
How durste ye saye for shame vnto yoᵘur love
That any thyng / might make you aferde
Han ye no mānnys / herte . and han a berde
Allas can ye ben a gaste . of swefnesse
Swefnesse engendreth / of replexions
Whan humoᵘurs ben / to haboundant in a wight
Certes this dreme whiche ye han had to night .
Cometh of the gret superfluite
Of youre rede coloure parde
Whiche causeth folke to dremen here dremes
Of arwes and of fyre wᵗith rede lemes
Of rede bestes that . wolen hem byte
Of contell and of whelpes gret ⁊and lyte
Right as the humoᵘur malencolye
Causith many a man in slepe to crye
For fere of bores and of boles blake
Or elles blake deuels wole hem take
Of other humos cowde I telle alsoo
That warken many a man in his slepe woo
But I wille passe as lightly as I can
Loo Caton which that was so wise a man
Saide he not thus ne doo no fors of dremes
Nowe sir qd she whan we flee fro tho bemes
For goddys love . as takith som laxatif
Vpon ꝑperill of my sowle . and of my lif
I counseile you the beste . I wille / not lye
That bothe of coloure and of malencoly
Ye purge you . and for ye shulle not tarye
Though that in this town is no Poticarye
I shall my self . to herbes techen yow .
That shalle ben youre hele ⁊and youre prowe
And in the gardyn / tho herbes . shalle I fynde
The whiche han hir ꝓpropirte . bekynde
To purgen you be nethe and eke aboue .
For yetith nought this / for goddes owne love
Ye ben full colrik / of complexioıı̄un
Where the sonne in / his assenciou
Ne fynde you replete of yoᵘur humoᵘurs hote /
And yf it doo . I dare wele leye a grote
That ye shalle haue a Feuer tercian
Or an agu . that may be youre beaute bane
A day or two . ye shalle haue digestiuesse .
Of wormes or ye take your laxatiuesse .
Of laureale sentaure . and of fumytere
Or elles of Elbore that groweth there
Of Catapuse or of gaytres buries
Of herbe yvy / growyng in oure yerd there mery is
Pek hem vp . right as they growe ⁊and ete hem ynne
Be mery husbond . for your fadres kynne
Dredith no dreme . I can seye you no more
Madame qd he gramercy / of your lore
But natheles as touching Daıı̄un Catou
That of wisdam soche gret renoun
By god men may in olde bokes rede .
On of the grettest auctoᵘur out of drede
Of many a man more of auctorite .
Than euer Caton was / so mot I the
That alle the Reuers . saithe of his sentence
And han wele founden by experience
That dremes ben significacions
As wele of ioye . and of tribulacions
That folke enduren in this lyf . present
There nedeth not to make of this noon argument
The verry preef . / shewith it in dede
Oon of the grettest Autoᵘur / that men rede
Saithe thus that whilom . two felawes wente
On pilgrimage . / in a full good entent
And happid soo . they / comen in a toun
Where as there was / soche congregacion
Of peple and eke of streight herbigage
That theye fande as mochell a cotage
In which they bothe might / I loggid be
Wherfor theye mosten of necessite
As for that night . departyn of company
And eche of hem gothe vnto his hostelrye
And toke his loggyng / as it wold falle
And seide allas . for in an oxes stalle
Ferre in a yerde / with oxen of the plouȝ
That other man was logged / wele I nouȝ
As was his aduenture or his fortune
That vs gouerneth . alle as in comune
And so be felle long or it / were daye
This man mette in his bed / there as he laye
How that his felawe gan on hym calle
And seid allas / for in an oxes stalle
This night shall I be murdred there I lye
Now helpe me dere brothir for I dye
In alle haste come to me he saide
This man oute of his slepe . for fere he brayde
But whan that he was wakened oute of his slepe
He turned hym / and toke of this no kepe
Hym thought his dreme was not but avanite
Thus twies in his slepyng dremed he
And at the thyrd tyme / yit his felawe
Came as hym thought / I am nowe I slawe
Be holde my blody woundes . / depe ⁊and wide
A rise vp erly / in the morown tyde
And at the west gate of the toun qd he
A Cartfull of donge there shalt þᵘ see
In which my body is hid / fulle priuely
Do thilke carte aresten boldlye
My gold causeth the mordre . sothe to sayne
And tolde hym euery poynt how he was slayne
With a fulle pitous face . / pale of hewe
And truste wele his dreme he fonde full trewe
For on the morowne / assone / as it was daye
To his felawes Inne / he toke the waye
And whan he come / to the Oxe stalle
After his felaw he be gan to calle
The Ostiler . answered hym a noon
And seid sir / youre Felaw is goon
Assone as daye / he went oute of the toun
This man gan falle / in gret suspecion
Remembryng . / on his dremes / that he mette
And forthe he gothe / no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto the west gate of the toun and fonde
A dunge carte as he wente to dunge londe
That was arayed in the same wise
As ye han herd the dede man devyse

l.hi: And with an hardy hert he gan to crye

div.l: And with an hardy hert he gan to crie
Vengeaunce . / and Iustice . / of this vilanye
My felaw / mordred is / this same night
And in this carte . / he lithe gapyng vpright
The dede man / that mordred / was alle newe
O blisfull god that art so iuste and trewe
Loo how that þᵘ be wreiest mordre alweye
Mordre wille . oute / that see we day / be daye
Mordre is so vilasom . and / abhominable
To god that is iuste . and resonable
That he ne woll not suffred helid be
They it a bide a yere or ij or thre
Mordre wille oute / this is my conclusioıı̄un
And right anoon / mynystres of the toıı̄un
Han heryte the carter . and sore hym pynede
And eke the Ostiler . so ferre engyned
That they be knewe . / hir wickednesse anoon
And weren hanged / be the nekke boon
Here men may se // that dremes ben to drede
And certes in the same bookes I rede
Right in the next Chapitre I herde of this
I gabbe not so haue I ioye or blys
Too men / that wolde han passed the see
For certayne cause . in to a ferre contree
Yf that the wynde ne had be contrarye
That made hym in a Cite / for to tarye
That stood full mery vpon / an hauen side
But on a day . ayens the yeuen tide
The wynde gan chaᵘnge / and blowe as him leste
Iolif and glad / they went vnto reste
And kisten hem full erlye / for to seyle
But herkene / that oo man fille in gret ꝑpereile
That oon of hem / in slepyng as he laye
He mette . a wonder swefne ayenst the daye
Hym thought a man . stood / be his beddys side
And hym cōmmaunded / that he sholde abide
And seid hym thus yf þᵘ to morowe wende
Þᵘ xalt be draynte / my tale is at an ende
He awook and tolde his felaw what he mette
And preied hym / his viage / for to lette
And for that daye he / preied hym for to abide
His felaw that laye . / by his beddys side
Gan for to laugh / and scorned hym fulle faste
No dreem qd he . may my herte agaste
That I wole lette / to do my thynges
I sette not a . strawe be dremynges
For swefnesse / ben but vanitees ⁊and iapes
Men dremen alweye . / of owles and of apes
And of many a . mase therwith alle
Men dremen of thyng þᵗat neuer was ne shall
But sithens I see þᵗat thou . wilt here abide
And thus for sleuthyn wilfully the tyde
God wot it rewith me . and haue good daye
And thus he toke his leve and went his waye
And er that he had half his . cours I seiled
Noot I nought why . / ne what myschaᵘnce it eylede
But casuelly . the shippes botme / rent
And shippe ⁊and man . vnder the water went
In sight of other shippes . hym beside
That wᵗith hym sailed at the same tide
And therfor / he saide . / Pertelote / so dere
By soche ensamples olde . maist þᵘ lere
That noman xolde be / to Recheles
Of dremes / for I seye the . doughtles
That many a dreeme . ful sore is for to drede
Loo in the lyf of seynt kenelme . mette a thyng I rede
That was kenelphus sone . / the noble kyng
Of Mertenrike how kenelme mette a thyng
A litle or . he was mordred on a daye .
His / mordre in his avisioıı̄un he saye
His Norice hym expouned euery dell
His swefne and bad hym kepe hym wele
For tresou / but he was vij yere olde
And ther for litle tale hathe he tolde
Of any dreme . / so holy was his herte
Be god I had leuer / than my sherte
That ye had herd / his legende / as haue I .
Dame Pertelote / I say you truly
Macrobeus . that writte the avisioıı̄un
Yn Affrik . of the worthy Ciprion
Affermeth dremes . / and saithe þᵗat there ben
Warnyng of thyngꝭes that men after seen
And therfor I pray you lokith wele
The olde testament of Danyell
Yf he helde / dremes of anye vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph . / and ye shall see .
Whethir dremes ben . som tyme . I say not alle
Warnyng of thyngꝭes . / that shulne after falle
Loke of Egipte . the kyng Pharaoo
His baker / and his botler also
Wheþ̉ere theye ne felt . / noon effecte of dremes
Whoso wille seche / the acte / of sondry Reames
Maye reden of Dremes / many a wonder thyng
Loo Cresus . whiche that was of . Luyde kyng
Mette he nought / that he sat vpon a tree
Which signified . that hanged sholde be
Loo here Adromacha . Ector his wif
That day that Ector . sholde lese his lif
She dremed / on the same night beforn
How that the lyf of Ector sholde be lorn
Yf thilke daye / he went in to batayle
She warnede hym . but it myght / not availe .
He went / for to fighten neuertheles
But he was slayne . / of Achilles
But thilke is alle to longe to telle
And eke it is nygh daye . I may not dwelle
Shortly . I saye as for conclusiou
That I shalle haue / of this avisiou
Of aduersitees / and I saye furthermore
That I nill telle / of laxatyues no store
For theye ben venymous . I wot right wele
I hem defye . I love hem neuer a dele
Now lete vs speke / of myrth ⁊and lete / stynt al this
Madame . Pertelote . so haue I blisse
Of oon thyng / god hathe sent me large grace
For whan I see / the beaute of your face
Ye ben so scarlet red abouten your eyȝen
It makith alle my dred / for to dyen
For also / siker as in principio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame . the sēntence of the latyn is
Wommān is mannys ioye . and alle his blis
For whan I feele . a night your softe side
Albe it that I may not on you ride
For that oure perche . / is made so . narwe alas
I am so fulle of ioye . and of solas
That I dyfie / bothe swefne ⁊and dreme
And with that worde he flyeth doun from the beme
For it was daye . / and eke his hennes alle
And wᵗith a chukke . he gan hem for to calle
For he had founde a corn . laye in the yarde
Reall he was nomore a . ferd
He federed / Pertelote . xxᵗⁱ tyme
And trad as ofte . / as it were prime
He loketh as it were a grym / lyoıı̄un
And on his toes . he romed . vp and doun
Hym deygned not to sette his feet on grounde
Ay chukked he whan he had . a corn . I founde .
And to hym . than ranne his wyfes alle
Thus roiall . as a prince . in his halle
Leve I this Chaunteclere . / in his pasture
And aftirward . wulle I telle . of his aduenture .
Whan the monthe . in which the world began
That hight Marche whan god furste made man
Was complet and passed were alsoo
Sethens Marche byganne thirty dayes and twoo
By felle that Chaunteclere . / in his his pride
His swefne seven wyfes . / walkyng hym beside
Cast vp his eyen . / to the bright sonne
That in the signe . of Taurus was I ronne
Twenty degrees . and oon / and somwhat more
He knewe bikynde . and be noon other lore
That it was prime / and crewe wᵗith blisfull steuen
The sonne he . sayde . / is clumben vpon heuen
Fourty degrees . and oon and . somwhat more I wys
Madame Pertelote / my worldes blisse
Herkene how these blisfull birdes syng
And se the fresshe / floures how they spryng
Full is myn herte . / of Reuell ⁊and solas
But sodeynly hym fille a sorowefull caas
For euer the latter ende . of ioye is sone agoo
And comonly often tyme . it fareth soo
And . yf Arthor . couthe faire endyte
He . in a Cronicle . myght savely write
As . for a souerayn . / notabilite
Now . euery wise man herkene me
This story is also trewe . I vndertake
As is the book of launcelot the lake
That wommen helde in full / gret reuerence
Now wille I torne . ayen to my sentence
A colefox / of skeith and iniquite
That in the groue was woned yeres thre
By high ymaginacioıı̄un . a forn caste
The same night / throughout / the hogge braste
In to the yerd . / there . Chaunteclere the faire
Was wont and eke his wyfes . to repaire
And in a Bedde . of wortes . / stille he laye
Tille . it was vnderne . / of the daye .
Waityng . his tyme . on Chaunteclere to falle
As gladly doon these homicides alle .
That in awaite / ligge to mordir menne .
O . false . morderer . / liggyng in thy denne
O . newe scarioot / and newe genylou
False . dissimulor . O . gret Symoıı̄un
That broughtest troye / alle outerly / to sorowe
O . Chauntecler . o . cursed be þᵗat morowe .
Þᵗat þᵘ in the yerde . / fleyȝe from the bemes
Thou were full wole I warned be thy dremes
That thilke daye . / was / ꝑperilouse to / the
But that god a fore . / mot nedes be
After the opinioıı̄un of certayne clerkes
Witnesse of hym / that any clerke is .
That in scole gret altercacioıı̄un
In this mater . and gret disputacioıı̄un
And hathe ben of an hundred thousand men
But I / ne can . bulte it to the bren
As can the holy doctour . Augustyn .
Or Boece . or the Busshoppe Bradwardyn
Wheþ̉ere that goddys wille . a for wetyng .
Streyneth me nedfully / for to doon a thyng
Nedly clepe . I / symple necessite
Or elles . yf the free choyse . / be graunted me .
To do that same thyng . or to doo it nought
Þᵘ god wot it . / or it was wrought
Or of his wetyng streyneth neuer a dell
But by necessite / condicionell
I wille not haue to doon of soche matere
My tale is of a cok . as ye shulne after here
That took his counseile . / of his wif wᵗith sorowe
To walken in the yerde . vpon the morowe
That he had . the mette . that I you tolde
Wommans counseile . / brought vs first to woo
Wommans counseile ben full ofte colde
And made Adam . / from paradys to goo
There he was full mery / and wele at ease
But for I not whom I might displease
If I counseile of wommen wolde blame
Passe oủere . for I seid . it in my game
Rede auctoᵘurs wher theye trete of soche matere .
And what they sayde of wommen here
These ben the cokkes wordes and not myn
I can noon harme . / of no womman devyne
Faire in the sonde . / to bathe here / merilye
Lithe Pertelote . / and alle here sustres bye
Ayen the sonne . / and Chaunteclere / so free
Sang meryer . than the meremayde in the see
For Phisialogus . / saithe wittirlye
How that theye syngen wele and merilye
And so by felle . as he caste his eyȝe
Amonges . the wortes vpon a boterflye .
He was ware of this Fox . / that laye full lowe
Nothyng ne luste hym thanne . for to crowe .
But cried anoon . cok cok / and vp he stirte
As a man that is afraied . in his herte .
For naturelly . a beste desireth . for to flee .
Fro his contrary . / if he may . it see .
Theye he had . neuer . seie it erst wᵗith / his eye
This Chaunteclere / whan he gan hym aspie
He wold han fledde / but that the Fox anoon
Saide gentille sir allas . what wole ye doon
Ben ye affraied . of me . / that am your freende
Certes / sir than ben ye vnkynde
If I wille to you . harme or vilanye
I am not come . / youre counseile to aspie
But truly the cause of my comyng
Was oonly to herken howe ye syng
For truly ye han in musik more felyng as mery a steuen

l.hi: Than had Boys or any can syng

div.l: As / any Aungel / hath that is in heuene
Therwith ye . han in musik more felyng
Than had Boys or any can syng
My lorde your fader / god his sowle blisse
And eke your moder of / here gentilnesse
Han in my house / ben / to your gret ease
And certes / sir . / full fayne wolde . I you plese
But for men speken of syngyng I you praye
So mote I brouke myn eyȝen / tweye
Save ye I ne / herd neuer . man syng
As did your / fader in the mornyng
Certes . it was of herte / alle that he sang
And for to make his voys . the more stronge
He wolde so peynen hym / þᵗat wᵗith his bothe eyen
He must wynke . so wolde he cryen
And stonden . on his tiptoos therwᵗithall
And stretche forthe his nek long ⁊and . small
And eke he was of soche discreciou
That there was noman in no Region
That hym in song or wisdom / might passe
I haue wele herd rad Daun Burell ther asse
Among his vers there was a cok
For a Preestis sone / yaf hym a knokke
Vpon his / legges / whiles he was . yong and nyse
Therfor he made hym . to lese . his benefice
But certayne there is . no comparisou
Betwix . / the wisdam . and discreciou
Of your fader . and of his subtilite
Now syngeth sir . / for seynt charite
Lat se . can ye your fadyr counterfete
This Chaunteclere . / his wynges gan to bete
As man . that cowde . nat this tresou aspie /
So wasse . he / rauisshed wᵗith his / flaterye .
Allas / ye . lordes . many a false . flatoure
Is in youre courte and many a losengoure
That plesen youthe more be my feithe
Than he that sothfastnesse vnto yow seithe
Redethe ecclesiastre of flaterye
Bethe ware . ye lordes of hir treccherie
This Chaunteclere . / stoode hiȝe vpon his toos
Strecchyng his nek and held . his eyen cloos
And gan to crowe lowde . for the nones
And Dame Russell / stirte vp all at ones
And by the gargate hente Chaunteclere
And on his bak toward the wode hym bere .
For yit was there noman hym sewed .
O destenye that . maiste not ben eschewed
Alas . that Chaunteclere . / felle from the bemes
Alas his wif ne rought not of dremes
And on a friday . felle alle this myschaunce .
O venus / that art goddesse of plesaunce
Sethyns that thy seruᵃnt was this Chaunteclere
And in thy seruice . dede alle / his powere
More for delite / than the worlde to multiplie
Why woldest þᵘ suffre on thy day to dye .
O gaufrede . dere maister souerayn
That whan . thy worthy kyng Richard was slayne
With shotte . complaynedest his dethe full sore
Why ne had I thy sentence . / and thy lore .
The Fryday . for to chiden as did ye
For oon a . frydaye / shortly slayne was he
Than wolde I showe you / how that I cowde pleyne .
For Chaunteclere / ⁊and for his peyne .
Certes soche . crye / ne lamentacioıı̄un
Was of ladies . made when ylioıı̄un
Was wonne / and Purrys / wᵗith his streight swerd
Whan he hent kyng Pryam . by the berde
And slewe hym . as . said Envidos
And maden alle the hennes . / in the cloos
Whan they had seye of Chaunteclere the sight
But souereinly / Dame Pertelote shrite
Full lowder than did / hasdrubaldes wif
Whan that hir husbond / had loste / his lif
And that the Romayns . had / brent Cartage
She was so full of torment . and of rage
That wilfully in to . the Fyre / she sterte
And breynt hir selff with a stedfast herte
O wofull hennes . right so cried ye
As whan that Nero brent the Citee
Of Rome Crieddys / the senatoures wyfes
For that hir . husbond sholde lese hir lyfes
Withoute gilt Nero . hathe hem slayne
Now woll I turne / to my tale ayain
This sely . and here doughters twoo
For seint Powle saithe . alle that writen is
To oure doctryne it is I writen I wys
Take the frute and letith the chaf be stille
Now good god yf that it be thy wille
As seithe my . lorde . so make vs . alle good men
And bryng vs . alle . to his high blisse Amen

l.hi: Here endith . the Nonnes prest tale .

div.l: (base) And here folweth the prologe of the Manciples tale
(base) Woot ye nat where ther stant a litel town
(base) Which that clepid is Bobbe vpanddown
(base) Vnder the Blee in Caunterbury weye
(base) Ther gan oure hoost for to iape and pleye
(base) And seyde sires what Don is in the Myre
(base) Is ther no man for preyere ne for hyre
(base) That wole awake oure felawe al bihynde
(base) A theef myghte hym ful lightly robbe and bynde
(base) Se how he nappeth se how for Cokkes bones
(base) That he wol falle from his hors atones
(base) Is that a Cook of Londoun with meschaunce
(base) Do hym come forth he knoweth his penaunce
(base) For he shal telle a tale by my fey
(base) Althogh it be nat worth a botel hey
(base) Awake thow Cook quod he god yeue thee sorwe
(base) What eyleth thee to slepe by the morwe
(base) Hastow had fleen al nyght or artow dronke
(base) Or hastow with som quene al nyght yswonke
(base) So that thow mayst nat holden vp thyn heed
(base) This Cook that was ful pale and no thyng reed
(base) Seyde to oure hoost so god my soule blesse
(base) As ther is falle on me swich heuynesse
(base) Noot I nat why that me were leuere slepe

div.l: (base) Than the beste galoun wyn in Chepe
(base) Wel quod the Manciple if it may don ese
(base) To thee sir Cook and to no wight displese
(base) Which that here rideth in this compaignye
(base) And that oure hoost wole of his curteisye
(base) I wole as now excuse thee of thy tale
(base) For in good feith thy visage is ful pale
(base) Thyne eyen daswen eek as that me thynketh
(base) And wel I woot thy breth ful soure stynketh
(base) That sheweth wel thow art nat wel disposed
(base) Of me certeyn thow shalt nat ben yglosed
(base) Se how he ganeth lo this dronken wight
(base) As though he wolde swolwe vs anon right
(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man by thy fader kyn
(base) The deuel of helle sette his foot ther yn
(base) Thy cursed breeth infecte wol vs alle
(base) Fy stynkynge swyn fy foule mote thee falle
(base) A taketh hede sires of this lusty man
(base) Now swete sire wol ye Iusten atte Fan
(base) Ther to me thynketh ye ben wel yshape
(base) I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a straw
(base) And with his speche the Cook wax wroth and wraw
(base) And on the Manciple bigan he nodde faste
(base) For lakke of speche and doun the hors hym caste
(base) Wher as he lay til that men vp hym took
(base) This was a fair chyuachee of a Cook
(base) Allas he nadde yholde hym by his ladel
(base) And er that he agayn were in his Sadel
(base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro
(base) To lifte hym vp and muchel care and wo
(base) So vnweldy was this sory palled goost
(base) And to the Manciple thanne spak oure hoost

div.l: (base) By cause drynke hath domynacioun
(base) Vpon this man by my sauacioun
(base) I trowe he lewedly telle wolde his tale
(base) For were it wyn or old or moisty Ale
(base) That he hath dronke he speketh in his nose
(base) And fneseth faste and eek he hath the pose
(base) He hath also to do moore than ynow
(base) To kepen hym and his capil out of the Slow
(base) And if he falle from his capil eft soone
(base) Than shal we alle haue ynow to doone
(base) In liftynge vp his heuy dronken cors
(base) Telle on thy tale of hym make I no fors
(base) But yet Manciple in feith thow art to nyce
(base) Thus openly repreue hym of his vice
(base) Another day he wole par auenture
(base) Reclayme thee and brynge thee to lure
(base) I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
(base) As for to pynchen at thy rekenynges
(base) That were nat honeste if it cam to preef
(base) No quod the Manciple that were a gret mescheef
(base) So myghte he lightly brynge me in the snare
(base) Yet hadde I leuere payen for the Mare
(base) Which he rit on than he sholde with me stryue
(base) I wol nat wrathe hym also mote I thryue
(base) That that I spak I seyde it in my bourde
(base) And wite what I haue here in a gourde
(base) A draughte of wyn ye of a rype grape
(base) And right anon ye shul seen a good Iape
(base) This Cook shal drynke ther of if I may
(base) Vp peyne of deeth he wol nat seye me nay
(base) And certeynly to tellen as it was
(base) Of this vessel the Cook drank faste allas

div.l: (base) What neded it he drank ynow biforn
(base) And whan he hadde powped in this horn
(base) To the Manciple he took the gourde agayn
(base) And of that drynke the Cook was wonder fayn
(base) And thanked hym in swich wise as he kowde
(base) Thanne gan oure hoost to laughen wonder lowde
(base) And seyde I se wel it is necessarie
(base) Where that we goon good drynke we with vs carye
(base) For that wol turne rancour and disese
(base) Tacord and loue a many a wrong appese
(base) O Bacus yblessed be thy name
(base) That so kanst turnen ernest in to game
(base) Worship and thank be to thy deitee
(base) Of that matere ye gete namoore for me
(base) Telle on thy Manciple I the preye
(base) Wel sir quod he now herkneth what I seye
(base) Here endeth the prologe of the Maunciple
(base) Explicit ꝓprophemiıı̄un
(base) Here bigynneth the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Narrat
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the mooste lusty bachiler
(base) In al this world and eek the beste Archer
(base) He slow Phitoun the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge agayn the sonne vpon a day
(base) And many another noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wroghte as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he koude on euery Mynstralcye
(base) And syngen that it was a melodye
(base) To heren of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kyng of Thebes Amphioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That with his syngyng walled that Citee
(base) Koude neuere syngen half so wel as he
(base) Ther to he was the semelieste man
(base) That is or was sith that the world bigan
(base) What nedeth it hise fetures to discryue
(base) For in this world was noon so fair on lyue
(base) He was therwith fulfild of gentillesse
(base) Of honour and of parfit worthynesse
(base) This Phebus that was flour of Bachelrye
(base) As wel in fredom as in Chiualrye
(base) For his desport in signe eek of victorie
(base) Of Phitoun so as telleth vs the storie
(base) Was wont to beren in his hand a bowe
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a Crowe
(base) Which in a Cage he fostred many a day
(base) And taughte it speke as men teche a Iay
(base) Whit was this Crowe as is a Snow whit swan
(base) And contrefete the speche of euery man
(base) He kowde whan he sholde telle a tale
(base) Ther with in al this world no nyghtyngale
(base) Beter syngen þan eny nyȝtyngale
(base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel
(base) Syngen so wonder myrily and weel
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
(base) Which that he louede moore than his lyf
(base) And nyght and day dide euere his diligence
(base) Hire for to plese and doon hire reuerence
(base) Saue oonly that the sothe if I shal sayn
(base) Ialous he was and wolde han kept hire fayn
(base) For hym were looth byiaped for to be
(base) And so is euery wight in swich degree
(base) But al for naught for it auaileth noght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) A good wyf that is clene in werk and thoght
(base) Sholde nat be kept in noon awayt certayn
(base) And trewely the labour is in vayn
(base) To kepe a shrewe .for it wol nat be
(base) This holde I for a verray nycetee
(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues
(base) Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyues
(base) But now to purpos as I first bigan
(base) This worthy Phebus dooth al that he kan
(base) To plesen hire wenynge for swich plesaunce
(base) And for his manhode and his gouernaunce
(base) That no man sholde han put hym from hire grace
(base) But god it woot ther may no man embrace
(base) As to destreyne a thyng which that nature
(base) Hath naturelly set in a creature
(base) Take any bryd and put it in a Cage
(base) And do al thyn entente and thy corage
(base) To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke
(base) Of alle deyntees that thow kanst bithynke
(base) And kepe it also clenly as thow may
(base) Although his Cage of gold be neuer so gay
(base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold
(base) Leuere in a Forest that is rude and cold
(base) Gon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse
(base) For euere this bryd wol doon his bisynesse
(base) To eschape out of his Cage if he may
(base) His libertee this bryd desireth ay
(base) Lat take a Cat and fostre hym wel with Milk
(base) And tendre flessh and make his couche of silk
(base) And lat hym seen a Mous go by the wal
(base) Anon he weyueth Milk and flessh and al
(base) And euery deyntee that is in that hous
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Swich appetit hath he to ete a Mous
(base) Lo heere hath lust his domynacioun
(base) And appetit flemeth discrecioun
(base) A she wolf hath also a vileyns kynde
(base) The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde
(base) And leest of reputacioun that wol she take
